grade_9_10.name: Linear Equations and Inequalities
grade_9_10.short_description: Students solve and graph linear equations and inequalities in one and two variables, including systems of equations. This foundational topic develops algebraic reasoning and problem-solving skills essential for higher mathematics.

sub_topics.name: Linear Equations in One Variable
sub_topics.short_description: Solving linear equations using properties of equality and applying them to real-world problems.

sub_topics.name: Solving Basic Linear Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Apply properties of equality to isolate variables and solve equations of the form ax + b = c.
example_tasks: Solve for x: 3x + 7 = 22
Solve for y: -2y + 15 = 3y - 10
A cell phone plan costs $40 per month plus $0.10 per text message. If the total bill is $52, write and solve an equation to find the number of text messages sent.

sub_topics.name: Multi-Step Equations with Variables on Both Sides
sub_topics.short_description: Solve equations that require multiple steps, including combining like terms and variables on both sides.
example_tasks: Two cars leave from the same point traveling in opposite directions. One travels at 55 mph and the other at 65 mph. Write and solve an equation to find when they will be 300 miles apart.

sub_topics.name: Literal Equations and Formulas
sub_topics.short_description: Rearrange formulas and equations to solve for a specified variable in terms of other variables.
example_tasks: Solve the formula P = 2l + 2w for w
The formula for converting Celsius to Fahrenheit is F = (9/5)C + 32. Solve for C.
The area of a trapezoid is given by A = (1/2)h(b₁ + b₂). Solve for b₁ and explain what this formula represents.

sub_topics.name: Linear Inequalities in One Variable
sub_topics.short_description: Solving and graphing linear inequalities, understanding inequality properties and notation.

sub_topics.name: Solving and Graphing Linear Inequalities
sub_topics.short_description: Apply properties of inequality to solve and represent solutions on a number line.
example_tasks: Solve and graph: 2x - 5 < 11
Solve and graph: -3x + 7 ≥ 22 (remember to reverse the inequality sign)
A student needs a test average of at least 85 to earn a B. If their first three test scores are 78, 88, and 82, what score must they earn on the fourth test? Write and solve an inequality.

sub_topics.name: Compound Inequalities
sub_topics.short_description: Solve and graph compound inequalities involving 'and' and 'or' statements.
example_tasks: Solve and graph: -3 < 2x + 1 ≤ 9
Solve and graph: x + 4 < 1 or 2x - 3 > 7
A manufacturing process requires the temperature to be between 150°F and 200°F inclusive. Write this as a compound inequality and solve for the Celsius temperature range (use C = (5/9)(F - 32)).

sub_topics.name: Absolute Value Inequalities
sub_topics.short_description: Solve inequalities involving absolute value and interpret solutions geometrically.
example_tasks: Solve and graph: |x - 3| < 5
Solve and graph: |2x + 1| ≥ 7
A machine is designed to fill bottles with 500 mL of liquid, with an acceptable error of no more than 15 mL. Write and solve an absolute value inequality to find the acceptable range of volumes.

sub_topics.name: Linear Equations in Two Variables
sub_topics.short_description: Graphing linear equations, finding slopes and intercepts, and writing equations in various forms.

sub_topics.name: Graphing Linear Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Graph lines using tables, intercepts, and slope-intercept form.
example_tasks: Graph the equation y = 2x - 3 by creating a table of values
Graph 3x + 4y = 12 using the x- and y-intercepts
A car rental company charges $30 per day plus $0.25 per mile. Write an equation for the total cost C in terms of miles driven m for one day, then graph the equation.

sub_topics.name: Slope and Rate of Change
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate and interpret slope as a rate of change in various contexts.
example_tasks: Find the slope of the line passing through points (2, 5) and (6, 13)
A water tank contains 500 gallons at time t = 0 and drains at a constant rate to 200 gallons at t = 6 hours. Find the rate of change (slope) and interpret its meaning.
Determine whether the lines y = (2/3)x + 1 and y = (2/3)x - 4 are parallel, perpendicular, or neither. Justify your answer using slopes.

sub_topics.name: Forms of Linear Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Write and convert between slope-intercept, point-slope, and standard forms of linear equations.
example_tasks: Write the equation of a line with slope -3 passing through the point (2, 5) in point-slope form, then convert to slope-intercept form
Convert the equation 4x - 2y = 10 to slope-intercept form and identify the slope and y-intercept
Write the equation of a line passing through (1, 4) and (3, 10). Express your answer in all three forms: slope-intercept, point-slope, and standard form.

sub_topics.name: Parallel and Perpendicular Lines
sub_topics.short_description: Identify and write equations of parallel and perpendicular lines using slope relationships.
example_tasks: Write the equation of a line parallel to y = 3x - 2 that passes through (1, 5)
Write the equation of a line perpendicular to 2x + 3y = 6 that passes through the origin
Given points A(1, 2), B(4, 8), C(7, 2), and D(4, -4), determine if line AB is perpendicular to line CD by analyzing their slopes.

sub_topics.name: Systems of Linear Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Solve systems of two linear equations using multiple methods and interpret solutions in context.

sub_topics.name: Solving Systems by Graphing
sub_topics.short_description: Graph two linear equations and identify the point of intersection as the solution.
example_tasks: Solve the system by graphing: y = 2x + 1 and y = -x + 7
Graph the system: 2x + y = 8 and x - y = 1. Verify your solution algebraically.

A movie theater charges $10 for adults and $6 for children. One day, 500 tickets were sold for a total of $3,800. Write a system of equations to represent this situation and solve by graphing to find the number of adult and child tickets sold.

sub_topics.name: Solving Systems by Substitution
sub_topics.short_description: Solve systems by isolating one variable and substituting into the other equation.
example_tasks: Solve using substitution: y = 3x - 5 and 2x + y = 10
Solve using substitution: 3x + 4y = 7 and x - 2y = 5
Two numbers have a sum of 50 and a difference of 12. Write and solve a system of equations using substitution to find the two numbers.

sub_topics.name: Solving Systems by Elimination
sub_topics.short_description: Solve systems by adding or subtracting equations to eliminate one variable.
example_tasks: Solve using elimination: 2x + 3y = 7 and 3x - 3y = 8
Solve using elimination: 4x + 5y = 14 and 3x - 2y = -13

A chemist needs to mix a 20% acid solution with a 50% acid solution to create 30 liters of a 35% acid solution. Set up and solve a system of equations using elimination to find how many liters of each solution are needed.

sub_topics.name: Special Systems: No Solution and Infinite Solutions
sub_topics.short_description: Identify and interpret systems that have no solution (parallel lines) or infinitely many solutions (same line).
example_tasks: Determine whether the system has one solution, no solution, or infinitely many solutions: 2x + 3y = 6 and 4x + 6y = 12
Solve and classify: y = 2x + 5 and 2x - y = 3

A company's revenue and costs are both given by linear equations. Under what circumstances would these equations represent: (a) a break-even point, (b) no break-even point (always losing money), or (c) always profitable? Relate each case to types of systems of equations.

sub_topics.name: Linear Inequalities in Two Variables
sub_topics.short_description: Graph linear inequalities and systems of linear inequalities in the coordinate plane.

sub_topics.name: Graphing Linear Inequalities
sub_topics.short_description: Graph linear inequalities by shading the appropriate half-plane and using solid or dashed boundary lines.
example_tasks: Graph the inequality: y > 2x - 3
Graph the inequality: 3x + 2y ≤ 12
A farmer can plant at most 100 acres of land with corn (c) and soybeans (s). Write and graph an inequality to represent this constraint.

sub_topics.name: Systems of Linear Inequalities
sub_topics.short_description: Graph systems of linear inequalities and identify the solution region.
example_tasks: Graph the system and shade the solution region: y ≥ x + 1 and y < -2x + 6
Graph the system: x + y ≤ 8, x ≥ 2, and y ≥ 1

A factory produces chairs and tables. Chairs take 2 hours to make and tables take 3 hours. Workers have at most 60 hours per week. The factory must make at least 10 chairs and at least 5 tables. Write and graph a system of inequalities representing these constraints, and identify a possible production combination.

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Linear Programming
sub_topics.short_description: Use systems of inequalities to solve optimization problems by finding maximum or minimum values.
example_tasks: Given the feasible region defined by x ≥ 0, y ≥ 0, 2x + y ≤ 10, and x + 2y ≤ 8, find the maximum value of P = 3x + 4y

A company makes products A and B. Product A generates $5 profit and B generates $8 profit. Constraints are: 2A + 3B ≤ 120 (material), A + 2B ≤ 70 (labor), A ≥ 0, B ≥ 0. Find the production levels that maximize profit.

A nutrition problem: A diet requires at least 60g of protein and at least 30g of fiber daily. Food X provides 10g protein and 5g fiber per serving, Food Y provides 5g protein and 10g fiber per serving. If Food X costs $2 per serving and Food Y costs $3 per serving, find the minimum cost diet that meets the requirements.

grade_9_10.name: Functions and Function Notation
grade_9_10.short_description: Students develop understanding of functions as mathematical relationships, including domain, range, function notation, and various representations. This topic establishes foundational concepts for all subsequent function studies.

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Define functions as special relationships where each input has exactly one output.

sub_topics.name: Defining and Identifying Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the definition of a function and identify functions from tables, graphs, equations, and mappings.
example_tasks: Determine whether the relation {(1, 3), (2, 5), (3, 7), (2, 9)} is a function. Explain your reasoning.
Use the vertical line test to determine which of the following graphs represent functions: a circle, a parabola opening upward, and a sideways parabola.

A store's pricing policy charges $5 per item for orders of 10 items or fewer, and $4 per item for orders of more than 10 items. Is the total cost a function of the number of items ordered? Explain why or why not.

sub_topics.name: Function Notation and Evaluation
sub_topics.short_description: Use function notation f(x) and evaluate functions for specific input values.
example_tasks: If f(x) = 3x - 7, find f(4), f(-2), and f(0)
Given g(x) = x² - 2x + 5, find g(3) and g(-1)
A ball is thrown upward and its height in feet after t seconds is given by h(t) = -16t² + 64t + 5. Find h(0), h(2), and h(4), and interpret what each value represents in the context of the problem.

sub_topics.name: Domain and Range
sub_topics.short_description: Identify and express the domain and range of functions from various representations.
example_tasks: Find the domain and range of the function f(x) = √(x - 3)
State the domain and range of the function shown in the graph of y = (x - 2)² + 1
A rectangular garden has a fixed perimeter of 40 meters. Express the area A as a function of the width w, and determine the practical domain and range for this real-world situation.

sub_topics.name: Multiple Representations of Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Represent functions using tables, graphs, equations, and verbal descriptions, and translate between representations.

sub_topics.name: Interpreting Function Graphs
sub_topics.short_description: Analyze graphs to extract information about function behavior, including intercepts and increasing/decreasing intervals.
example_tasks: From the graph of a function, identify the x-intercepts, y-intercept, and intervals where the function is increasing or decreasing
A graph shows the temperature throughout a day. Identify the time when the temperature was highest, when it was increasing most rapidly, and estimate the average rate of change between 6 AM and noon.
Compare two functions representing the distance traveled by two cars. Use their graphs to determine which car was traveling faster at t = 3 hours and which car traveled farther overall.

sub_topics.name: Function Tables and Patterns
sub_topics.short_description: Create function tables, identify patterns, and determine function rules from tables.
example_tasks: Complete the table for f(x) = 2x² - 3 for x values: -2, -1, 0, 1, 2. Describe any patterns you observe.
Given the table with x: 1, 2, 3, 4 and f(x): 5, 9, 13, 17, determine the function rule

A sequence follows the pattern where the first term is 3 and each subsequent term is 2 more than twice the previous term. Create a table for the first 5 terms and write a function rule for the nth term if possible.

sub_topics.name: Translating Between Representations
sub_topics.short_description: Convert functions between different representations and understand how each representation provides unique insights.
example_tasks: Given the equation f(x) = -2x + 5, create a table of values and sketch the graph
A function is described verbally: 'The output is 3 less than twice the input.' Write this as an equation, create a table, and graph it.
A graph shows a linear function passing through (0, 4) and (2, 10). Write the equation of the function and create a table showing at least 5 input-output pairs.

sub_topics.name: Operations with Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Perform arithmetic operations with functions and understand composition of functions.

sub_topics.name: Adding and Subtracting Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Combine functions through addition and subtraction and evaluate the resulting functions.
example_tasks: If f(x) = 2x + 3 and g(x) = x - 5, find (f + g)(x) and (f - g)(x)
Given f(x) = x² and g(x) = 3x + 1, find (f + g)(2) and (f - g)(-1)

A company's revenue is R(x) = 50x and its cost is C(x) = 20x + 300, where x is the number of units. The profit function is P(x) = R(x) - C(x). Find the profit function and determine the profit when 20 units are sold.

sub_topics.name: Multiplying and Dividing Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Combine functions through multiplication and division, considering domain restrictions.
example_tasks: If f(x) = x + 2 and g(x) = x - 3, find (f · g)(x) and (f/g)(x), stating any domain restrictions
Given f(x) = 2x and g(x) = x² - 4, evaluate (f · g)(3) and (g/f)(2)

The length of a rectangle is given by l(x) = 2x + 1 and the width is w(x) = x - 2. Express the area A(x) as a function of x by multiplying the two functions. What is the practical domain for this situation?

sub_topics.name: Composition of Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Compose functions by substituting one function into another and interpret composed functions.
example_tasks: If f(x) = 2x + 1 and g(x) = x², find f(g(x)) and g(f(x)). Are they equal?
Given f(x) = √x and g(x) = x - 4, find (f ∘ g)(x) and state its domain

A store applies a 20% discount to items, then charges 8% sales tax. If the original price is x, write d(x) for the price after discount and t(x) for the price after tax. Find (t ∘ d)(x) to represent the final price, and explain why the order matters.

sub_topics.name: Inverse Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the concept of inverse functions, determine if a function has an inverse, and find inverse functions algebraically and graphically.

sub_topics.name: Understanding Inverse Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Define inverse functions as functions that 'undo' each other and verify inverse relationships.
example_tasks: Verify that f(x) = 2x - 3 and g(x) = (x + 3)/2 are inverse functions by showing f(g(x)) = x and g(f(x)) = x
Given the points (1, 3), (2, 5), (3, 7) on function f, list the corresponding points on its inverse f⁻¹
A function converts degrees Fahrenheit to Celsius: C(F) = (5/9)(F - 32). Find the inverse function and explain what it represents.

sub_topics.name: Finding Inverse Functions Algebraically
sub_topics.short_description: Use algebraic techniques to find inverse functions by switching x and y and solving for y.
example_tasks: Find the inverse function of f(x) = 3x + 7
Find the inverse of g(x) = (x - 2)/5 and verify your answer
A function converts miles to kilometers: k(m) = 1.609m. Find the inverse function and use it to convert 100 kilometers to miles.

sub_topics.name: Graphical Properties of Inverse Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Understand that inverse functions are reflections across the line y = x and apply the horizontal line test.
example_tasks: Sketch the graph of f(x) = 2x - 1 and its inverse on the same coordinate plane. Include the line y = x.
Use the horizontal line test to determine whether f(x) = x² has an inverse function. Explain your reasoning.
A function f passes through points (1, 4), (2, 7), and (3, 10). Without finding the equation, sketch the graph of f⁻¹ by reflecting these points across y = x.

grade_9_10.name: Linear and Exponential Functions
grade_9_10.short_description: Students compare and contrast linear and exponential growth patterns, model real-world situations with both function types, and analyze their key features. This topic emphasizes distinguishing between constant and proportional rates of change.

sub_topics.name: Linear Function Models
sub_topics.short_description: Model real-world situations with linear functions and interpret slope and intercepts in context.

sub_topics.name: Creating Linear Models
sub_topics.short_description: Develop linear function models from verbal descriptions, data sets, and real-world scenarios.
example_tasks: A taxi charges a $3 flat fee plus $2.50 per mile. Write a linear function C(m) for the cost in terms of miles m traveled.
A water tank contains 800 gallons and is being drained at a rate of 25 gallons per minute. Write a linear function V(t) for the volume remaining after t minutes.
Given data points showing a linear relationship between hours studied and test scores: (2, 75), (4, 82), (6, 89), find a linear model and predict the score for 5 hours of study.

sub_topics.name: Interpreting Linear Parameters
sub_topics.short_description: Interpret the meaning of slope and y-intercept in context and use them to make predictions.
example_tasks: A function P(t) = 250 + 30t represents a population, where t is years after 2020. Interpret the meaning of 250 and 30 in this context.
A linear function models the cost of a gym membership: C(m) = 50 + 40m, where m is the number of months. What do the y-intercept and slope represent?
The temperature of a cooling object is given by T(t) = 180 - 5t, where t is time in minutes. What was the initial temperature? What does the slope indicate about the cooling process?

sub_topics.name: Average Rate of Change
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate and interpret average rate of change over an interval for linear and non-linear functions.
example_tasks: Find the average rate of change of f(x) = 3x - 2 over the interval [1, 5]
A car's distance from home is given by d(t) = 45t, where t is hours. Find the average rate of change from t = 1 to t = 3 and explain what it represents.
For f(x) = x², find the average rate of change over [2, 4] and [4, 6]. Compare these rates and explain why they differ even though f is not linear.

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Exponential Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Understand exponential functions, their properties, and how they differ from linear functions.

sub_topics.name: Exponential Growth Models
sub_topics.short_description: Model situations involving exponential growth using functions of the form f(x) = a·bˣ where b > 1.
example_tasks: A bacteria population doubles every hour. If there are initially 50 bacteria, write an exponential function P(t) for the population after t hours.
An investment of $1,000 grows by 5% each year. Write an exponential function A(t) for the account value after t years.

A social media post is shared by 3 people, and each of them shares it with 3 more people, and so on. Write a function for the number of people who see the post at stage n, assuming the pattern continues.

sub_topics.name: Exponential Decay Models
sub_topics.short_description: Model situations involving exponential decay using functions of the form f(x) = a·bˣ where 0 < b < 1.
example_tasks: A car's value depreciates by 15% each year. If the car initially costs $25,000, write an exponential function V(t) for its value after t years.
A radioactive substance has a half-life of 8 days. If there are initially 100 grams, write a function M(t) for the mass remaining after t days.
A hot cup of coffee cools so that its temperature decreases by 10% each minute. If the initial temperature is 180°F, write an exponential function T(t) and find the temperature after 5 minutes.

sub_topics.name: Comparing Linear and Exponential Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Identify and distinguish between linear and exponential patterns in tables, graphs, and contexts.
example_tasks: Determine whether the table represents linear or exponential growth: x: 0, 1, 2, 3; y: 3, 6, 12, 24. Justify your answer.

Two investments are compared: Investment A grows by adding $100 per year; Investment B grows by 10% per year. Both start at $1,000. Which will be worth more after 10 years? Explain using the concepts of linear vs. exponential growth.
A population grows from 1,000 to 1,200 in year 1, then from 1,200 to 1,440 in year 2. Is this growth pattern linear or exponential? Write an appropriate function model.

sub_topics.name: Properties of Exponential Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Analyze key features of exponential functions including growth/decay factors, y-intercepts, and asymptotes.

sub_topics.name: Graphing Exponential Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Graph exponential functions and identify key features including asymptotes, intercepts, and end behavior.
example_tasks: Graph f(x) = 2ˣ and identify the y-intercept, horizontal asymptote, domain, and range
Graph g(x) = (1/2)ˣ and describe how it differs from f(x) = 2ˣ
Compare the graphs of y = 2ˣ, y = 3ˣ, and y = 5ˣ. How does the base affect the steepness of the graph?

sub_topics.name: Solving Basic Exponential Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Solve exponential equations by rewriting with common bases and using properties of exponents.
example_tasks: Solve: 2ˣ = 32
A population of 500 animals grows according to P(t) = 500(1.08)^t. In how many years will the population reach 1,000? (Estimate by testing values or graphing.)

sub_topics.name: Transformations of Exponential Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Apply transformations to exponential functions and understand their effects on the graph.
example_tasks: Describe how the graph of g(x) = 2^(x-3) differs from f(x) = 2ˣ
Graph h(x) = -2ˣ + 4 and identify all transformations applied to the parent function f(x) = 2ˣ
A bacteria population is modeled by P(t) = 100(2)^t. If the experiment starts with a 3-hour delay, write the new function P(t) that accounts for this delay.

sub_topics.name: Geometric Sequences as Exponential Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Connect geometric sequences to exponential functions and use both representations to solve problems.

sub_topics.name: Defining Geometric Sequences
sub_topics.short_description: Identify geometric sequences and find common ratios and specific terms.
example_tasks: Determine if the sequence 3, 6, 12, 24, 48 is geometric. If so, find the common ratio.
Find the 8th term of the geometric sequence: 5, 15, 45, 135, ...
A ball bounces to 60% of its previous height after each bounce. If it's dropped from 100 feet, how high will it bounce on the 5th bounce?

sub_topics.name: Explicit Formula for Geometric Sequences
sub_topics.short_description: Write and use the explicit formula aₙ = a₁·r^(n-1) for geometric sequences.
example_tasks: Write an explicit formula for the geometric sequence with first term 7 and common ratio 3
The second term of a geometric sequence is 12 and the fifth term is 96. Find the first term and common ratio, then write the explicit formula.
A salary increases by 4% each year. If the starting salary is $40,000, write a formula for the salary in year n and calculate the salary in year 10.

sub_topics.name: Connecting Geometric Sequences to Exponential Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Understand that geometric sequences are discrete exponential functions and convert between representations.
example_tasks: The geometric sequence aₙ = 2(3)^(n-1) can be written as the exponential function f(x) = a·3ˣ. Find the value of a.
An exponential function f(x) = 50(1.1)ˣ models a population. Create a table showing the population at x = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4 and explain how this table represents a geometric sequence.
Compare continuous exponential growth f(t) = 100(1.05)^t with the geometric sequence representing the value at whole number years. Under what conditions are they equivalent?

grade_9_10.name: Quadratic Functions and Equations
grade_9_10.short_description: Students analyze quadratic functions through multiple representations, solve quadratic equations using various methods, and apply quadratic models to real-world situations. This topic develops understanding of parabolas and their key features.

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Quadratic Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Identify and graph quadratic functions, understanding their basic shape and key features.

sub_topics.name: Identifying Quadratic Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Recognize quadratic functions in various forms and distinguish them from linear and other function types.
example_tasks: Identify which of the following are quadratic functions: f(x) = 3x², g(x) = 2x + 5, h(x) = x² - 4x + 1, k(x) = 1/x²
A table shows values: x: -2, -1, 0, 1, 2; y: 6, 2, 0, 0, 2. Determine if this could represent a quadratic function by examining second differences.
Explain why the area of a square with side length s is a quadratic function, while the perimeter is a linear function.

sub_topics.name: Key Features of Parabolas
sub_topics.short_description: Identify the vertex, axis of symmetry, y-intercept, and x-intercepts of parabolas from graphs and equations.
example_tasks: From the graph of a parabola, identify the vertex, axis of symmetry, y-intercept, and x-intercepts
For f(x) = x² - 4x + 3, find the y-intercept and determine whether the parabola opens upward or downward
A parabola has its vertex at (2, -3) and passes through the point (0, 1). Does it open upward or downward? Explain your reasoning.

sub_topics.name: Graphing Quadratics in Standard Form
sub_topics.short_description: Graph quadratic functions in standard form f(x) = ax² + bx + c and identify key features.
example_tasks: Graph f(x) = x² - 4x + 3 by creating a table of values. Identify the vertex and axis of symmetry.
For g(x) = -2x² + 4x + 1, determine if the parabola opens upward or downward, find the y-intercept, and sketch the graph
A ball is thrown upward with height function h(t) = -16t² + 48t + 4, where t is time in seconds. Graph this function and determine when the ball hits the ground.

sub_topics.name: Forms of Quadratic Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Work with quadratic functions in standard, vertex, and factored forms, understanding the advantages of each.

sub_topics.name: Vertex Form
sub_topics.short_description: Use vertex form f(x) = a(x - h)² + k to identify the vertex and graph parabolas efficiently.
example_tasks: Identify the vertex of f(x) = 2(x - 3)² + 5 without graphing
Write a quadratic function in vertex form with vertex at (-2, 4) that opens downward
Graph g(x) = -(x + 1)² - 2 by applying transformations to the parent function f(x) = x²

sub_topics.name: Factored Form
sub_topics.short_description: Use factored form f(x) = a(x - p)(x - q) to identify x-intercepts quickly and graph parabolas.
example_tasks: Find the x-intercepts of f(x) = (x - 2)(x + 5)
Write a quadratic function in factored form with x-intercepts at x = -3 and x = 4 that passes through the point (0, -12)
A projectile's height is h(x) = -2(x - 1)(x - 7), where x is horizontal distance. Interpret what the x-intercepts represent in this context.

sub_topics.name: Converting Between Forms
sub_topics.short_description: Convert quadratic functions between standard, vertex, and factored forms as needed for different purposes.
example_tasks: Convert f(x) = x² - 6x + 8 to factored form
Convert g(x) = (x - 1)(x + 3) to standard form
Complete the square to convert h(x) = x² + 4x + 1 to vertex form

sub_topics.name: Solving Quadratic Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Solve quadratic equations using multiple methods including factoring, square roots, completing the square, and the quadratic formula.

sub_topics.name: Solving by Factoring
sub_topics.short_description: Solve quadratic equations by factoring and applying the zero product property.
example_tasks: Solve: x² + 7x + 12 = 0
Solve: 2x² - 5x - 3 = 0
The area of a rectangular garden is 60 square feet. The length is 4 feet more than the width. Set up and solve a quadratic equation to find the dimensions.

sub_topics.name: Solving Using Square Roots
sub_topics.short_description: Solve quadratic equations of the form (x - h)² = k by taking square roots of both sides.
example_tasks: Solve: (x - 5)² = 16
Solve: 3(x + 2)² = 27
A square patio has an area of 144 square feet. Find the side length of the patio by solving x² = 144.

sub_topics.name: Completing the Square
sub_topics.short_description: Solve quadratic equations by completing the square and understand this method's connection to vertex form.
example_tasks: Solve by completing the square: x² + 6x + 2 = 0
Solve by completing the square: x² - 8x + 10 = 0
Complete the square to convert f(x) = 2x² - 12x + 14 to vertex form, then find the vertex

sub_topics.name: The Quadratic Formula
sub_topics.short_description: Apply the quadratic formula x = (-b ± √(b² - 4ac)) / (2a) to solve any quadratic equation.
example_tasks: Use the quadratic formula to solve: 2x² + 5x - 3 = 0
Solve: x² - 4x + 1 = 0 and express answers in simplest radical form
A projectile's height is given by h(t) = -4.9t² + 20t + 2 meters. Use the quadratic formula to find when the projectile hits the ground (h = 0).

sub_topics.name: The Discriminant and Nature of Solutions
sub_topics.short_description: Use the discriminant to determine the number and type of solutions to quadratic equations without solving.

sub_topics.name: Analyzing the Discriminant
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate b² - 4ac and interpret its value to determine if solutions are real, rational, or complex.
example_tasks: Without solving, determine the nature of solutions for x² + 5x + 6 = 0 using the discriminant
For the equation 2x² - 4x + 5 = 0, use the discriminant to determine if solutions are real or complex
For what values of k will the equation x² + kx + 9 = 0 have exactly one real solution?

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Complex Solutions
sub_topics.short_description: Understand that quadratics with negative discriminants have complex solutions involving i = √(-1).
example_tasks: Solve x² + 4 = 0 and express your answer using i
Solve 2x² + 2x + 5 = 0 using the quadratic formula and simplify using i
Explain why the graph of f(x) = x² + 2x + 5 has no x-intercepts, relating this to the discriminant and complex solutions.

sub_topics.name: Choosing Solution Methods
sub_topics.short_description: Select the most efficient method for solving quadratic equations based on the equation's form and coefficients.
example_tasks: For each equation, state which method (factoring, square roots, completing the square, or quadratic formula) would be most efficient: (a) x² - 9 = 0, (b) x² + 6x - 2 = 0, (c) (x - 3)² = 7, (d) 2x² + 7x + 3 = 0
Explain why the equation x² + 5x + 3 = 0 is best solved using the quadratic formula rather than factoring
Solve x² - 8x + 15 = 0 using two different methods and verify that you get the same solutions

sub_topics.name: Applications of Quadratic Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Model real-world situations with quadratic functions and interpret key features in context.

sub_topics.name: Projectile Motion
sub_topics.short_description: Model the height of projectiles using quadratic functions and solve related problems.
example_tasks: A ball is thrown upward with an initial velocity of 40 ft/s from a height of 5 feet. Its height is given by h(t) = -16t² + 40t + 5. Find the maximum height and when it occurs.
A rocket is launched with height function h(t) = -4.9t² + 98t + 10 meters. How long does it take to reach maximum height? What is the maximum height?
Two projectiles are launched simultaneously. Projectile A: h₁(t) = -16t² + 64t, Projectile B: h₂(t) = -16t² + 48t + 32. Which reaches a greater maximum height? When are they at the same height?

sub_topics.name: Area and Optimization Problems
sub_topics.short_description: Use quadratic functions to model and solve area and optimization problems.
example_tasks: A farmer has 200 feet of fencing to enclose a rectangular area. Express the area as a function of the width and find the dimensions that maximize the area.

A rectangular piece of cardboard is 10 inches by 16 inches. Squares of side length x are cut from each corner to form an open box. Express the volume as a function of x and find the value of x that maximizes volume.
A company's profit P (in thousands) is modeled by P(x) = -2x² + 20x - 32, where x is the number of items produced (in thousands). How many items should be produced to maximize profit?

sub_topics.name: Revenue and Profit Models
sub_topics.short_description: Apply quadratic functions to business contexts involving revenue, cost, and profit.
example_tasks: A company sells widgets for $50 each. They sell 1000 per month. For each $2 decrease in price, they sell 100 more widgets. Express revenue R as a function of the number of price decreases x, and find the price that maximizes revenue.
The revenue from selling x units is R(x) = 100x - 0.5x² and the cost is C(x) = 20x + 500. Find the profit function P(x) = R(x) - C(x) and determine how many units should be sold to maximize profit.
A ticket price p and attendance n are related by n = 5000 - 100p. Revenue is R = p·n. Express R as a function of p, find the ticket price that maximizes revenue, and calculate the maximum revenue.

grade_9_10.name: Polynomial Operations and Factoring
grade_9_10.short_description: Students perform arithmetic operations with polynomials and apply various factoring techniques. This topic builds algebraic fluency essential for advanced mathematics and develops understanding of polynomial structure.

sub_topics.name: Understanding Polynomials
sub_topics.short_description: Identify, classify, and evaluate polynomials based on degree and number of terms.

sub_topics.name: Polynomial Terminology and Classification
sub_topics.short_description: Understand and use vocabulary including terms, coefficients, degree, and classify polynomials as monomials, binomials, or trinomials.
example_tasks: Identify the degree, leading coefficient, and constant term of the polynomial 4x³ - 2x² + 7x - 5
Classify each polynomial by degree and number of terms: (a) 3x² - 5, (b) 7x⁴, (c) x³ - 2x² + x - 8
Write a polynomial in standard form with degree 4, leading coefficient 2, and constant term -3

sub_topics.name: Evaluating Polynomials
sub_topics.short_description: Substitute values into polynomial expressions and evaluate using proper order of operations.
example_tasks: Evaluate P(x) = 2x³ - 5x² + 3x - 1 for x = 2
If f(x) = x⁴ - 3x² + 2, find f(-1), f(0), and f(2)
The volume of a box is given by V(x) = x³ + 6x² + 9x cubic inches. Find the volume when x = 3 inches.

sub_topics.name: End Behavior of Polynomials
sub_topics.short_description: Determine the end behavior of polynomial functions based on degree and leading coefficient.
example_tasks: Describe the end behavior of f(x) = 2x⁴ - 3x² + 1 as x → ∞ and x → -∞
For g(x) = -x⁵ + 4x³ - 2x, determine if the ends of the graph point in the same or opposite directions
Match each polynomial with its end behavior: (a) f(x) = x³, (b) g(x) = -x⁴, (c) h(x) = 2x⁵

sub_topics.name: Adding and Subtracting Polynomials
sub_topics.short_description: Combine polynomials by adding and subtracting like terms using horizontal and vertical formats.

sub_topics.name: Adding Polynomials
sub_topics.short_description: Add polynomials by combining like terms and simplifying the result.
example_tasks: Find the sum: (4x³ - 2x² + x - 5) + (x³ + 3x² - 4x + 1)
The length of a rectangle is represented by 2x² + 3x + 1 and the width by x² - x + 4. Find the expression for the perimeter.

sub_topics.name: Subtracting Polynomials
sub_topics.short_description: Subtract polynomials by distributing the negative sign and combining like terms.
example_tasks: Subtract: (5x² + 3x - 8) - (2x² - 4x + 3)
Find the difference: (x³ + 4x² - 2x + 7) - (3x³ - x² + 5x - 2)
The total cost of producing x items is C(x) = 3x² + 50x + 200 and the revenue is R(x) = 5x² + 80x. Write and simplify an expression for profit P(x) = R(x) - C(x).

sub_topics.name: Combining Multiple Polynomials
sub_topics.short_description: Simplify expressions involving multiple additions and subtractions of polynomials.
example_tasks: Simplify: (2x² + 3x - 1) + (x² - 5x + 4) - (3x² + x - 2)
Simplify: 2(x² + 3x - 5) - 3(2x² - x + 1) + (x² + 4)
Three people contribute to a fundraiser. Person A contributes x² + 50, Person B contributes 2x² - 30, and Person C contributes -x² + 100. Write and simplify an expression for the total contribution.

sub_topics.name: Multiplying Polynomials
sub_topics.short_description: Multiply polynomials using distributive property, FOIL method, and area models.

sub_topics.name: Multiplying Monomials and Polynomials
sub_topics.short_description: Apply the distributive property to multiply monomials by polynomials.
example_tasks: Multiply: 3x(2x² - 5x + 4)
Multiply: -2x²(x³ - 3x² + x - 6)
The area of a rectangle is found by multiplying length l = 2x + 5 by width w = 3x. Find the expression for the area.

sub_topics.name: Multiplying Binomials
sub_topics.short_description: Multiply two binomials using FOIL (First, Outer, Inner, Last) or other methods.
example_tasks: Multiply using FOIL: (x + 4)(x + 7)
Multiply: (2x - 3)(3x + 5)
Find the product: (x + 2y)(3x - y)

sub_topics.name: Special Products
sub_topics.short_description: Recognize and apply patterns for squaring binomials and difference of squares.
example_tasks: Expand using the pattern (a + b)² = a² + 2ab + b²: (x + 5)²
Expand using the pattern (a - b)² = a² - 2ab + b²: (3x - 2)²
Multiply using the difference of squares pattern (a + b)(a - b) = a² - b²: (2x + 3)(2x - 3)

sub_topics.name: Multiplying General Polynomials
sub_topics.short_description: Multiply polynomials with more than two terms using distributive property or area models.
example_tasks: Multiply: (x + 2)(x² - 3x + 4)
Multiply: (2x - 1)(x² + 3x - 5)
Find the product: (x + 1)(x + 2)(x + 3)

sub_topics.name: Factoring Polynomials
sub_topics.short_description: Factor polynomials using various techniques including GCF, grouping, and special patterns.

sub_topics.name: Factoring Out the Greatest Common Factor
sub_topics.short_description: Identify and factor out the greatest common factor from polynomial terms.
example_tasks: Factor completely: 6x³ + 9x² - 15x
Factor: 4x²y - 8xy² + 12xy
The volume of a rectangular prism is 2x³ + 6x² + 4x cubic units. Factor this expression to represent possible dimensions.

sub_topics.name: Factoring Trinomials
sub_topics.short_description: Factor trinomials of the form x² + bx + c and ax² + bx + c.
example_tasks: Factor: x² + 7x + 12
Factor: x² - 5x - 24
Factor: 2x² + 7x + 3

sub_topics.name: Factoring Difference of Squares
sub_topics.short_description: Recognize and factor expressions in the form a² - b² = (a + b)(a - b).
example_tasks: Factor: x² - 25
Factor: 4x² - 49
Factor completely: 3x² - 75

sub_topics.name: Factoring Perfect Square Trinomials
sub_topics.short_description: Recognize and factor perfect square trinomials of the form a² ± 2ab + b².
example_tasks: Factor: x² + 10x + 25
Factor: 4x² - 12x + 9
Determine if x² + 8x + 16 is a perfect square trinomial and factor it

sub_topics.name: Factoring by Grouping
sub_topics.short_description: Factor polynomials with four terms by grouping pairs of terms strategically.
example_tasks: Factor by grouping: x³ + 3x² + 2x + 6
Factor: 2x³ - 4x² + 3x - 6
Factor completely: 6x³ + 9x² - 4x - 6

sub_topics.name: Dividing Polynomials
sub_topics.short_description: Divide polynomials using long division and synthetic division methods.

sub_topics.name: Polynomial Long Division
sub_topics.short_description: Divide polynomials using the long division algorithm similar to numerical long division.
example_tasks: Divide (x² + 7x + 12) by (x + 3) using long division
Divide (2x³ - 5x² + 3x - 8) by (x - 2)
Use long division to divide (x³ + 1) by (x + 1) and express the result as quotient + remainder/divisor

sub_topics.name: Synthetic Division
sub_topics.short_description: Use synthetic division as a shortcut for dividing polynomials by linear factors of the form (x - c).
example_tasks: Use synthetic division to divide (x³ + 2x² - 5x + 12) by (x - 3)
Divide (2x⁴ - 3x³ + x - 5) by (x + 2) using synthetic division
Use synthetic division to determine if (x - 4) is a factor of x³ - 2x² - 11x + 12

sub_topics.name: Remainder and Factor Theorems
sub_topics.short_description: Apply the Remainder Theorem to evaluate polynomials and the Factor Theorem to identify factors.
example_tasks: Use the Remainder Theorem to find the remainder when P(x) = x³ - 4x² + 6x - 2 is divided by (x - 2)
Determine if (x + 3) is a factor of P(x) = x³ + 5x² + 8x + 6 using the Factor Theorem
Find the value of k such that (x - 1) is a factor of x³ - 2x² + kx - 3

grade_9_10.name: Rational Expressions and Equations
grade_9_10.short_description: Students simplify rational expressions, perform operations with them, and solve rational equations. This topic extends fraction arithmetic to algebraic expressions and develops understanding of domain restrictions.

sub_topics.name: Simplifying Rational Expressions
sub_topics.short_description: Simplify rational expressions by factoring and canceling common factors, identifying domain restrictions.

sub_topics.name: Understanding Rational Expressions
sub_topics.short_description: Define rational expressions and identify values that make the denominator zero (excluded values).
example_tasks: Identify the values of x for which the rational expression (x + 3)/(x - 5) is undefined
State the domain of f(x) = (2x + 1)/(x² - 9)
Explain why x cannot equal 0 or -2 in the expression (x - 3)/(x² + 2x)

sub_topics.name: Simplifying by Factoring
sub_topics.short_description: Simplify rational expressions by factoring numerators and denominators and canceling common factors.
example_tasks: Simplify: (x² - 4)/(x + 2)
Simplify: (x² + 5x + 6)/(x² + 7x + 10)
Simplify: (2x² - 8)/(4x - 8) and state any restrictions on x

sub_topics.name: Simplifying Complex Rational Expressions
sub_topics.short_description: Simplify rational expressions with more complex numerators and denominators.
example_tasks: Simplify: (x³ - 8)/(x² - 4)
Simplify: (x² - x - 6)/(x² - 9)
Simplify: (2x² + 5x - 3)/(2x² - x - 1) and identify excluded values

sub_topics.name: Multiplying and Dividing Rational Expressions
sub_topics.short_description: Perform multiplication and division operations with rational expressions.

sub_topics.name: Multiplying Rational Expressions
sub_topics.short_description: Multiply rational expressions by multiplying numerators and denominators, then simplifying.
example_tasks: Multiply and simplify: (x/3) · (6/x²)
Multiply and simplify: (2x + 6)/(x² - 9) · (x - 3)/(4x + 12)

sub_topics.name: Dividing Rational Expressions
sub_topics.short_description: Divide rational expressions by multiplying by the reciprocal of the divisor.
example_tasks: Divide and simplify: (x/4) ÷ (x²/8)
Divide and simplify: (3x + 9)/(x² - 16) ÷ (x + 3)/(2x - 8)

sub_topics.name: Combined Multiplication and Division
sub_topics.short_description: Perform operations involving both multiplication and division of rational expressions.
example_tasks: Simplify: (x/2) · (4/x²) ÷ (2/x)
A rectangle has length (x² - 4)/(x + 1) and width (x + 1)/(x - 2). Find the area and divide by the height (x + 2)/(2x - 4) to find a simplified expression for the volume per unit height.

sub_topics.name: Adding and Subtracting Rational Expressions
sub_topics.short_description: Add and subtract rational expressions by finding common denominators and combining numerators.

sub_topics.name: Adding and Subtracting with Like Denominators
sub_topics.short_description: Combine rational expressions that have the same denominator by adding or subtracting numerators.

sub_topics.name: Adding and Subtracting with Unlike Denominators
sub_topics.short_description: Find the least common denominator (LCD) and rewrite rational expressions before combining.
example_tasks: Subtract: 5/(x - 2) - 3/(x + 3)

sub_topics.name: Complex Addition and Subtraction
sub_topics.short_description: Combine rational expressions with polynomial denominators requiring factoring to find the LCD.
example_tasks: Subtract: (x + 1)/(x² + 5x + 6) - (x - 2)/(x² + 4x + 3)

sub_topics.name: Solving Rational Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Solve equations containing rational expressions by eliminating denominators and checking for extraneous solutions.

sub_topics.name: Solving Simple Rational Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Solve rational equations by multiplying both sides by the LCD to eliminate fractions.
example_tasks: Solve: x/3 + x/4 = 7
Solve: 3/x = 5/(x + 2)

sub_topics.name: Extraneous Solutions
sub_topics.short_description: Identify and exclude extraneous solutions that make denominators equal to zero.
example_tasks: Solve and check for extraneous solutions: 1/x + 1/(x - 2) = 1
Solve: (x + 3)/(x - 2) = 4/(x - 2). Explain why one solution is extraneous.
Solve: 2/(x + 1) + 3/(x - 1) = 4/(x² - 1) and verify all solutions

sub_topics.name: Applications of Rational Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Apply rational equations to solve work-rate, distance-rate-time, and mixture problems.
example_tasks: One pipe can fill a pool in 4 hours, another in 6 hours. How long will it take both pipes working together? Set up and solve a rational equation.
A boat travels 20 miles upstream in the same time it travels 30 miles downstream. If the current is 5 mph, find the boat's speed in still water.
A cyclist travels 60 miles. If she had traveled 3 mph faster, the trip would have taken 1 hour less. Find her actual speed by setting up and solving a rational equation.

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Rational Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Graph rational functions and identify key features including asymptotes, intercepts, and holes.

sub_topics.name: Vertical Asymptotes
sub_topics.short_description: Identify vertical asymptotes by finding values where the denominator equals zero (and numerator doesn't).
example_tasks: Find the vertical asymptote(s) of f(x) = 3/(x - 2)
Identify vertical asymptotes of g(x) = (x + 1)/(x² - 9)
Explain why f(x) = (x² - 4)/(x - 2) has a hole at x = 2 rather than a vertical asymptote

sub_topics.name: Horizontal Asymptotes
sub_topics.short_description: Determine horizontal asymptotes by comparing degrees of numerator and denominator polynomials.
example_tasks: Find the horizontal asymptote of f(x) = (2x + 3)/(x - 1)
Find the horizontal asymptote of g(x) = (3x² + 1)/(x² - 4)
Compare the horizontal asymptotes of f(x) = (2x)/(x + 1) and g(x) = (2x²)/(x + 1). Explain the difference.

sub_topics.name: Graphing Rational Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Sketch graphs of rational functions by identifying asymptotes, intercepts, and analyzing behavior near asymptotes.
example_tasks: Graph f(x) = 1/(x - 3) by identifying the vertical and horizontal asymptotes, then plotting key points
Sketch the graph of g(x) = (x + 2)/(x - 1), labeling all asymptotes and intercepts
Graph h(x) = (x² - 4)/(x² - 1) and identify any holes, asymptotes, and intercepts

grade_9_10.name: Radical Expressions and Equations
grade_9_10.short_description: Students work with radical expressions, rational exponents, and solve radical equations. This topic connects radical and exponential notation while developing skills for manipulating and solving equations involving roots.

sub_topics.name: Simplifying Radical Expressions
sub_topics.short_description: Simplify square roots and higher-order radicals using properties of radicals and prime factorization.

sub_topics.name: Simplifying Square Roots
sub_topics.short_description: Simplify square root expressions by factoring out perfect squares.
example_tasks: Simplify: √72
Simplify: √(50x³y²)
Simplify: 3√32 + 2√8

sub_topics.name: Simplifying Cube Roots and Higher-Order Roots
sub_topics.short_description: Simplify cube roots and higher-order radicals using perfect powers.
example_tasks: Simplify: ∛(54)
Simplify: ∜(80x⁴y⁵)

sub_topics.name: Rationalizing Denominators
sub_topics.short_description: Eliminate radicals from denominators by multiplying by appropriate forms of 1.
example_tasks: Rationalize the denominator: 5/√3
Rationalize: (√2)/(√8)
Rationalize: 3/(2√5)

sub_topics.name: Operations with Radical Expressions
sub_topics.short_description: Perform addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division with radical expressions.

sub_topics.name: Adding and Subtracting Radicals
sub_topics.short_description: Combine like radicals by adding or subtracting coefficients.
example_tasks: Simplify: 3√5 + 7√5
Simplify: 4√12 - 2√3
Simplify: √18 + √32 - √50

sub_topics.name: Multiplying Radical Expressions
sub_topics.short_description: Multiply radical expressions using the product property √a · √b = √(ab).
example_tasks: Multiply and simplify: √3 · √12
Multiply: (2√5)(3√10)
Multiply using FOIL: (√3 + 2)(√3 - 5)

sub_topics.name: Dividing Radical Expressions
sub_topics.short_description: Divide radical expressions and rationalize denominators when necessary.
example_tasks: Divide and simplify: √48 ÷ √3
Rationalize and simplify: (√6)/(√2 + 1)

sub_topics.name: Rationalizing Using Conjugates
sub_topics.short_description: Rationalize denominators containing binomials with radicals by multiplying by the conjugate.
example_tasks: Rationalize: 1/(√5 - 2)
Rationalize: (3 + √2)/(3 - √2)

sub_topics.name: Rational Exponents
sub_topics.short_description: Convert between radical notation and rational exponent notation and simplify expressions with rational exponents.

sub_topics.name: Understanding Rational Exponents
sub_topics.short_description: Interpret and evaluate expressions with rational exponents using the relationship aᵐ/ⁿ = ⁿ√(aᵐ).
example_tasks: Evaluate: 27^(1/3)
Evaluate: 16^(3/4)
Convert to radical form: x^(2/5)

sub_topics.name: Simplifying Expressions with Rational Exponents
sub_topics.short_description: Apply properties of exponents to simplify expressions containing rational exponents.
example_tasks: Simplify: (8x^6)^(1/3)

sub_topics.name: Negative Rational Exponents
sub_topics.short_description: Simplify expressions with negative rational exponents using the property a^(-m/n) = 1/a^(m/n).
example_tasks: Evaluate: 16^(-1/2)
Simplify: x^(-2/3) · x^(5/3)
Write with positive exponents only: (x^(-3/4))/(y^(-1/2))

sub_topics.name: Solving Radical Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Solve equations containing radicals by isolating the radical and raising both sides to appropriate powers.

sub_topics.name: Solving Simple Radical Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Solve radical equations with one radical term by isolating and squaring both sides.
example_tasks: Solve: √(x + 3) = 5
Solve: 2√x - 5 = 3

sub_topics.name: Extraneous Solutions in Radical Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Check solutions to identify and exclude extraneous solutions introduced by squaring.
example_tasks: Solve and check: √(x + 1) = x - 5
Solve: √(2x + 3) = x. Identify any extraneous solutions.
Solve: √(x² - 4) = x - 2 and verify all solutions in the original equation

sub_topics.name: Equations with Multiple Radicals
sub_topics.short_description: Solve equations containing two or more radical expressions.
example_tasks: Solve: √x + √(x + 7) = 7

sub_topics.name: Applications of Radical Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Apply radical equations to solve real-world problems involving formulas with square roots.
example_tasks: The distance d (in miles) to the horizon from a height h (in feet) is given by d = √(1.5h). If you can see 15 miles to the horizon, how high above sea level are you?
The period T of a pendulum is given by T = 2π√(L/32), where L is the length in feet. Find the length needed for a period of 2 seconds.
The speed v in mph of a car before braking can be estimated by v = √(24d), where d is the length of skid marks in feet. If skid marks are 120 feet long, estimate the speed before braking.

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Complex Numbers
sub_topics.short_description: Understand imaginary numbers, perform operations with complex numbers in the form a + bi.

sub_topics.name: The Imaginary Unit i
sub_topics.short_description: Define i = √(-1) and simplify square roots of negative numbers.
example_tasks: Simplify: √(-16)
Simplify: √(-50)
Evaluate: i², i³, i⁴

sub_topics.name: Operations with Complex Numbers
sub_topics.short_description: Add, subtract, multiply, and divide complex numbers.
example_tasks: Multiply: (2 + 3i)(1 - 2i)
Divide: (3 + 2i)/(1 - i) by multiplying by the conjugate

sub_topics.name: Complex Conjugates
sub_topics.short_description: Use complex conjugates to divide complex numbers and simplify expressions.
example_tasks: Find the product of (4 + 3i) and its conjugate
Simplify: (2 - i)/(3 + 2i)
If z = 5 + 2i, find z · z̄ (where z̄ is the conjugate of z)

grade_9_10.name: Geometry: Congruence and Proof
grade_9_10.short_description: Students explore geometric relationships, congruence of figures, and formal proof techniques. This topic develops logical reasoning skills and establishes foundations for deductive geometry.

sub_topics.name: Fundamental Geometric Concepts
sub_topics.short_description: Review points, lines, planes, angles, and their relationships and properties.

sub_topics.name: Points, Lines, and Planes
sub_topics.short_description: Identify and describe relationships among points, lines, and planes using proper notation.
example_tasks: Use proper notation to name three collinear points, two lines that intersect, and a plane containing four points
Determine if the following statement is always, sometimes, or never true: 'Two lines intersect at exactly one point.' Explain.
Given three non-collinear points A, B, and C, how many distinct lines can be drawn through pairs of these points?

sub_topics.name: Angle Relationships
sub_topics.short_description: Identify and apply properties of complementary, supplementary, vertical, and adjacent angles.
example_tasks: Two angles are complementary. One angle measures 37°. Find the measure of the other angle.
Angles A and B are vertical angles. If m∠A = 3x + 10 and m∠B = 5x - 20, find the value of x and the measure of both angles.
Two parallel lines are cut by a transversal. Identify all pairs of corresponding angles, alternate interior angles, and alternate exterior angles.

sub_topics.name: Parallel and Perpendicular Lines
sub_topics.short_description: Apply properties of parallel lines cut by transversals and perpendicular line relationships.
example_tasks: Two parallel lines are cut by a transversal. One angle measures 75°. Find the measures of all other angles formed.
If line m is perpendicular to line n, and line n is perpendicular to line p, what is the relationship between lines m and p? Justify your answer.
Given parallel lines with a transversal, if one interior angle on the same side measures (2x + 15)° and the other measures (3x - 5)°, find x.

sub_topics.name: Triangle Congruence
sub_topics.short_description: Prove triangles congruent using SSS, SAS, ASA, AAS, and HL congruence postulates and theorems.

sub_topics.name: Triangle Congruence Postulates
sub_topics.short_description: Apply SSS, SAS, ASA, and AAS postulates to prove triangles congruent.
example_tasks: Given triangles ABC and DEF with AB = DE, BC = EF, and AC = DF, which congruence postulate proves the triangles congruent?
Two triangles have two pairs of congruent angles and one pair of congruent non-included sides. Which postulate (if any) proves congruence?
Determine if you can prove △ABC ≅ △XYZ using the given information: ∠A ≅ ∠X, AB = XY, ∠B ≅ ∠Y. If so, state the postulate.

sub_topics.name: Corresponding Parts of Congruent Triangles
sub_topics.short_description: Use CPCTC (Corresponding Parts of Congruent Triangles are Congruent) to prove additional relationships.
example_tasks: Given △ABC ≅ △DEF, list all pairs of corresponding congruent parts
Prove that if △ABC ≅ △DEF by SAS, then AC = DF using CPCTC
In quadrilateral ABCD, diagonal AC bisects angles A and C, and AB = BC. Prove that AD = CD using triangle congruence and CPCTC.

sub_topics.name: Isosceles and Equilateral Triangles
sub_topics.short_description: Apply theorems about isosceles and equilateral triangles including base angles and special properties.
example_tasks: In isosceles triangle ABC with AB = AC, if ∠B = 65°, find m∠A and m∠C
Prove that if a triangle is equilateral, then it is also equiangular
In isosceles triangle DEF with DE = DF, the measure of ∠D is (2x + 10)° and the measure of ∠E is (3x - 20)°. Find x and all angle measures.

sub_topics.name: Right Triangle Congruence
sub_topics.short_description: Apply the Hypotenuse-Leg (HL) theorem to prove right triangles congruent.
example_tasks: Two right triangles have congruent hypotenuses and one pair of congruent legs. Explain why they must be congruent.
In right triangles ABC and DEF with right angles at C and F, if AB = DE and BC = EF, prove the triangles are congruent.
Can you prove two right triangles congruent if you only know their hypotenuses are equal? Explain why or why not.

sub_topics.name: Geometric Proof Techniques
sub_topics.short_description: Write formal two-column proofs, paragraph proofs, and flow proofs using logical reasoning.

sub_topics.name: Two-Column Proofs
sub_topics.short_description: Construct formal two-column proofs with statements and reasons in logical sequence.
example_tasks: Write a two-column proof: Given: ∠1 and ∠2 are supplementary, ∠2 and ∠3 are supplementary. Prove: ∠1 ≅ ∠3
Given: AB || CD, ∠1 ≅ ∠2. Prove: ∠3 ≅ ∠4 (where angles are formed by a transversal)
Write a proof that the base angles of an isosceles triangle are congruent using a two-column format

sub_topics.name: Paragraph Proofs
sub_topics.short_description: Write informal paragraph-style proofs that present logical arguments in narrative form.
example_tasks: Write a paragraph proof: If two angles are both congruent and supplementary, prove they are right angles.
Given that vertical angles are congruent, write a paragraph proof explaining why
Write a paragraph proof that if a point is on the perpendicular bisector of a segment, it is equidistant from the endpoints

sub_topics.name: Proof Planning and Strategies
sub_topics.short_description: Develop strategies for planning proofs including working backwards and identifying needed theorems.
example_tasks: Given: Point M is the midpoint of AB and CD, AB || CD. What would you need to prove that △AMC ≅ △BMD? Outline a proof strategy.
To prove that a quadrilateral is a parallelogram, list three different sets of conditions you could use
Explain the strategy of 'working backwards' in proof writing using an example

sub_topics.name: Transformations and Congruence
sub_topics.short_description: Use transformations (translations, rotations, reflections) to establish and understand congruence.

sub_topics.name: Rigid Motions
sub_topics.short_description: Identify and perform translations, rotations, and reflections that preserve distance and angle measure.
example_tasks: Translate triangle ABC with vertices A(1, 2), B(3, 4), C(2, 5) using the rule (x, y) → (x + 3, y - 2). Find the coordinates of A'B'C'.
Reflect point P(4, -3) across the x-axis, then across the y-axis. What are the final coordinates?
Rotate point A(3, 0) 90° counterclockwise about the origin. What are the coordinates of A'?

sub_topics.name: Defining Congruence with Transformations
sub_topics.short_description: Understand that two figures are congruent if one can be mapped onto the other using rigid motions.
example_tasks: Describe a sequence of rigid motions that maps △ABC to △DEF if they are congruent
Two triangles are congruent. Explain why there must exist a sequence of rigid motions mapping one to the other.
Given △ABC with vertices A(0, 0), B(3, 0), C(0, 4) and △DEF with vertices D(5, 1), E(8, 1), F(5, 5), describe transformations showing they are congruent.

sub_topics.name: Line and Rotational Symmetry
sub_topics.short_description: Identify lines of symmetry and rotational symmetry in geometric figures.
example_tasks: How many lines of symmetry does a regular hexagon have? Draw and describe them.
Determine the rotational symmetry of an equilateral triangle. What is the minimum angle of rotation?
Does a parallelogram have line symmetry? Rotational symmetry? Explain your answers.

sub_topics.name: Properties of Triangles
sub_topics.short_description: Explore special segments in triangles including medians, altitudes, angle bisectors, and perpendicular bisectors.

sub_topics.name: Triangle Midsegments
sub_topics.short_description: Apply the Triangle Midsegment Theorem relating midsegments to triangle sides.
example_tasks: In △ABC, D and E are midpoints of AB and AC respectively. If BC = 14, find DE.
The midsegment of a triangle is parallel to the third side and measures 8 cm. What is the length of the third side?
Prove that the segment connecting the midpoints of two sides of a triangle is parallel to the third side and half its length

sub_topics.name: Medians and Centroids
sub_topics.short_description: Understand that medians intersect at the centroid, which divides each median in a 2:1 ratio.
example_tasks: In △ABC, the medians meet at centroid G. If AG = 12, find the length of the entire median from A.
Explain why every triangle has exactly one centroid
The vertices of a triangle are A(0, 0), B(6, 0), and C(3, 6). Find the coordinates of the centroid.

sub_topics.name: Altitudes and Orthocenters
sub_topics.short_description: Identify altitudes of triangles and understand that they intersect at the orthocenter.
example_tasks: In a right triangle, where is the orthocenter located? Explain.
Draw an obtuse triangle and construct all three altitudes. Where does the orthocenter lie?
In △ABC with vertices A(0, 0), B(6, 0), C(3, 4), find the equation of the altitude from C to AB

sub_topics.name: Perpendicular Bisectors and Circumcenters
sub_topics.short_description: Apply the property that perpendicular bisectors of a triangle's sides meet at the circumcenter.
example_tasks: Point P is equidistant from the vertices of △ABC. What is point P called and where is it located?
The perpendicular bisectors of two sides of a triangle intersect at point O. Prove that O is equidistant from all three vertices.
In △ABC, the circumcenter is outside the triangle. What type of triangle is △ABC?

grade_9_10.name: Geometry: Similarity and Trigonometry
grade_9_10.short_description: Students explore similar figures, prove triangles similar, and apply right triangle trigonometry. This topic connects proportional reasoning with geometric relationships and introduces trigonometric ratios.

sub_topics.name: Similarity and Scale Factors
sub_topics.short_description: Understand similar figures, scale factors, and relationships between corresponding parts.

sub_topics.name: Understanding Similar Figures
sub_topics.short_description: Identify similar figures and understand that corresponding angles are congruent and sides are proportional.
example_tasks: Two rectangles are similar with dimensions 4 by 6 and 10 by 15. Find the scale factor.
If △ABC ~ △DEF with scale factor 3:2, and AB = 12, find DE
Are all squares similar to each other? Are all rectangles similar to each other? Explain your reasoning.

sub_topics.name: Scale Factors and Proportions
sub_topics.short_description: Use scale factors to find unknown lengths and solve problems involving similar figures.
example_tasks: Two similar triangles have a scale factor of 2:5. If the smaller triangle has a perimeter of 18 cm, find the perimeter of the larger triangle.
A model car is built to a scale of 1:24. If the model is 7 inches long, how long is the actual car in feet?
Two similar polygons have areas of 36 cm² and 64 cm². What is the ratio of their corresponding side lengths?

sub_topics.name: Area and Volume Ratios of Similar Figures
sub_topics.short_description: Apply the relationship between scale factors and area/volume ratios for similar figures.
example_tasks: Two similar triangles have a side length ratio of 3:4. What is the ratio of their areas?
Two similar cylinders have a scale factor of 2:3. If the smaller cylinder has a volume of 48 cm³, find the volume of the larger cylinder.
A photograph measuring 4 inches by 6 inches is enlarged so that the longer side is 15 inches. What is the area of the enlarged photograph?

sub_topics.name: Triangle Similarity
sub_topics.short_description: Prove triangles similar using AA, SAS, and SSS similarity theorems.

sub_topics.name: Angle-Angle (AA) Similarity
sub_topics.short_description: Apply the AA Similarity Postulate to prove triangles similar.
example_tasks: In △ABC and △DEF, ∠A ≅ ∠D and ∠B ≅ ∠E. Prove that △ABC ~ △DEF.
Two triangles have angles measuring 40° and 60°. Explain why the triangles must be similar.
A tree casts a shadow 24 feet long at the same time a 6-foot person casts a 4-foot shadow. Use similar triangles to find the height of the tree.

sub_topics.name: SAS and SSS Similarity
sub_topics.short_description: Use SAS and SSS similarity theorems to prove triangles similar.
example_tasks: △ABC has sides AB = 6, BC = 9, and ∠B = 50°. △DEF has sides DE = 4, EF = 6, and ∠E = 50°. Are the triangles similar? Explain.
Two triangles have sides in the ratios 2:3:4 and 6:9:12. Prove they are similar using SSS Similarity.
Given △ABC with sides 5, 7, 9 and △DEF with sides 10, 14, 18, explain why △ABC ~ △DEF

sub_topics.name: Applications of Triangle Similarity
sub_topics.short_description: Apply triangle similarity to solve indirect measurement and real-world problems.
example_tasks: A person 5.5 feet tall casts a shadow 8 feet long. At the same time, a building casts a shadow 96 feet long. Find the height of the building.
A ladder leaning against a wall forms similar triangles. If a 20-foot ladder reaches 16 feet up the wall, how high would a 30-foot ladder reach at the same angle?
On a map with scale 1 inch = 50 miles, two cities are 3.5 inches apart. What is the actual distance between the cities?

sub_topics.name: Pythagorean Theorem
sub_topics.short_description: Apply the Pythagorean Theorem and its converse to solve problems and classify triangles.

sub_topics.name: Applying the Pythagorean Theorem
sub_topics.short_description: Use a² + b² = c² to find missing side lengths in right triangles.
example_tasks: Find the length of the hypotenuse of a right triangle with legs of 5 and 12.
A right triangle has a hypotenuse of 17 cm and one leg of 8 cm. Find the length of the other leg.
A 13-foot ladder is placed 5 feet from the base of a wall. How high up the wall does the ladder reach?

sub_topics.name: Converse of the Pythagorean Theorem
sub_topics.short_description: Use the converse to determine if a triangle is right, acute, or obtuse.
example_tasks: Determine if a triangle with sides 7, 24, and 25 is a right triangle.
A triangle has sides of lengths 5, 9, and 12. Is this triangle acute, right, or obtuse?
Three vertices of a quadrilateral are A(0, 0), B(5, 0), and C(5, 12). If D is at (0, 12), prove that the quadrilateral contains right angles using the Pythagorean Theorem.

sub_topics.name: Special Right Triangles (45-45-90 and 30-60-90)
sub_topics.short_description: Apply side relationships in 45-45-90 and 30-60-90 triangles to solve problems efficiently.
example_tasks: In a 45-45-90 triangle, if each leg has length 7, find the length of the hypotenuse.
In a 30-60-90 triangle, the hypotenuse has length 20. Find the lengths of both legs.
A square has a diagonal of 10√2 inches. Find the length of each side and the area of the square.

sub_topics.name: Distance Formula and Pythagorean Theorem
sub_topics.short_description: Derive and apply the distance formula as an application of the Pythagorean Theorem.
example_tasks: Find the distance between points A(3, 7) and B(9, 15)
A triangle has vertices at A(1, 2), B(5, 5), and C(8, 1). Find the perimeter of the triangle.
Determine if the triangle with vertices P(-2, 1), Q(2, 4), and R(5, 0) is isosceles by comparing side lengths

sub_topics.name: Right Triangle Trigonometry
sub_topics.short_description: Define and apply sine, cosine, and tangent ratios to solve right triangle problems.

sub_topics.name: Trigonometric Ratios
sub_topics.short_description: Define sine, cosine, and tangent as ratios of sides in right triangles and evaluate them.
example_tasks: In a right triangle with legs 3 and 4 and hypotenuse 5, find sin A, cos A, and tan A where A is the angle opposite the leg of length 3.
If sin θ = 5/13, find cos θ and tan θ (assume θ is acute)
A right triangle has an angle of 40° and a hypotenuse of 10. Set up (but don't solve) expressions for finding the lengths of both legs using sine and cosine.

sub_topics.name: Solving Right Triangles
sub_topics.short_description: Use trigonometric ratios to find unknown sides and angles in right triangles.
example_tasks: In right triangle ABC with right angle C, if ∠A = 35° and AC = 20, find AB (the hypotenuse).
A right triangle has one leg of length 15 and an adjacent angle of 28°. Find the length of the hypotenuse.
In a right triangle, one leg is 8 and the hypotenuse is 17. Find the measure of the acute angles to the nearest degree.

sub_topics.name: Angles of Elevation and Depression
sub_topics.short_description: Apply trigonometry to problems involving angles of elevation and depression.
example_tasks: From a point 100 feet from the base of a building, the angle of elevation to the top is 32°. Find the height of the building.
A person standing on a cliff 150 feet above sea level observes a boat at an angle of depression of 18°. How far is the boat from the base of the cliff?
A 50-foot wire is attached to the top of a pole and anchored to the ground 30 feet from the base. Find the angle the wire makes with the ground.

sub_topics.name: Applications of Trigonometry
sub_topics.short_description: Solve real-world problems using right triangle trigonometry.
example_tasks: A wheelchair ramp must have a maximum incline of 5°. If the ramp must reach a height of 3 feet, what is the minimum horizontal distance required?
An airplane climbs at an angle of 12° for a ground distance of 5000 feet. How much altitude has it gained?
Two buildings are 80 feet apart. From the top of the shorter building (40 feet tall), the angle of elevation to the top of the taller building is 25°. Find the height of the taller building.

sub_topics.name: Geometric Mean in Right Triangles
sub_topics.short_description: Apply geometric mean relationships in right triangles including altitude to hypotenuse.

sub_topics.name: Altitude to the Hypotenuse
sub_topics.short_description: Use the relationship that the altitude to the hypotenuse creates similar triangles.
example_tasks: In right triangle ABC with altitude CD to hypotenuse AB, if AD = 4 and DB = 9, find CD.
The altitude to the hypotenuse of a right triangle divides the hypotenuse into segments of lengths 3 and 12. Find the length of the altitude.
In a right triangle, the altitude to the hypotenuse is 6 and one segment of the hypotenuse is 4. Find the length of the other segment and the entire hypotenuse.

sub_topics.name: Leg and Segment Relationships
sub_topics.short_description: Apply the geometric mean to find relationships between legs and hypotenuse segments.
example_tasks: In a right triangle, an altitude to the hypotenuse divides it into segments of 5 and 20. Find the length of each leg of the triangle.
A right triangle has legs of length 6 and 8. Find the lengths of the segments of the hypotenuse created by the altitude to the hypotenuse.
Prove that in a right triangle with altitude to the hypotenuse, each leg is the geometric mean between the hypotenuse and the adjacent segment

sub_topics.name: Applications of Geometric Mean
sub_topics.short_description: Solve problems involving geometric mean in various contexts.
example_tasks: The geometric mean of two numbers is 12 and one of the numbers is 8. Find the other number.
Find two consecutive integers whose geometric mean is approximately 7.5

In architecture, a golden rectangle has its length and width in the golden ratio. If the width is 10 feet and the length is 16.18 feet, verify this is approximately the golden ratio (1.618) and find the geometric mean of the dimensions.

grade_9_10.name: Circles and Geometric Measurement
grade_9_10.short_description: Students explore properties of circles including arcs, angles, chords, and tangents, and calculate arc length, sector area, and volumes of three-dimensional figures. This topic integrates circular geometry with measurement formulas.

sub_topics.name: Circle Terminology and Properties
sub_topics.short_description: Identify parts of circles and understand basic circle relationships.

sub_topics.name: Parts of a Circle
sub_topics.short_description: Identify and define radius, diameter, chord, secant, and tangent.
example_tasks: In circle O, if the radius is 8 cm, what is the diameter? If chord AB = 12 cm, is it a diameter?
Draw a circle and label a radius, diameter, chord (that is not a diameter), secant, and tangent.
True or false: Every diameter is a chord, but not every chord is a diameter. Explain your reasoning.

sub_topics.name: Central and Inscribed Angles
sub_topics.short_description: Understand the relationship between central angles, inscribed angles, and their intercepted arcs.
example_tasks: A central angle measures 80°. What is the measure of its intercepted arc?
An inscribed angle intercepts an arc of 100°. What is the measure of the inscribed angle?
If a central angle and an inscribed angle intercept the same arc, and the central angle measures 120°, what is the measure of the inscribed angle?

sub_topics.name: Arcs and Arc Measure
sub_topics.short_description: Classify arcs as minor, major, or semicircles and find arc measures.
example_tasks: In circle O, if central angle AOB measures 75°, find the measures of minor arc AB and major arc AB.
Points A, B, and C lie on a circle. If arc AB = 100° and arc BC = 130°, find arc AC (the minor arc).
A circle is divided into three arcs by points A, B, and C. If the arcs are in the ratio 2:3:4, find the measure of each arc.

sub_topics.name: Angles in Circles
sub_topics.short_description: Apply theorems about angles formed by chords, secants, and tangents.

sub_topics.name: Inscribed Angle Theorem
sub_topics.short_description: Apply the theorem that an inscribed angle is half the measure of its intercepted arc.
example_tasks: An inscribed angle measures 42°. Find the measure of its intercepted arc.
Arc ABC measures 160°. Find the measure of inscribed angle ABC.
Prove that an angle inscribed in a semicircle is a right angle

sub_topics.name: Angles Formed by Chords, Secants, and Tangents
sub_topics.short_description: Find measures of angles formed by intersecting chords, secants, and tangents.
example_tasks: Two chords intersect inside a circle, forming an angle. If the intercepted arcs measure 80° and 60°, find the measure of the angle formed.
A tangent and a secant are drawn from an external point. If the intercepted arcs are 120° and 40°, find the measure of the angle formed.
Two secants are drawn from an external point. The intercepted arcs measure 100° and 30°. Find the angle between the secants.

sub_topics.name: Properties of Tangent Lines
sub_topics.short_description: Apply the property that a tangent is perpendicular to the radius at the point of tangency.
example_tasks: A tangent to a circle meets a radius at point P. If the radius is 10 cm and makes a right angle with the tangent, explain why.
Two tangents are drawn to a circle from an external point. Prove that the tangent segments are congruent.

A tangent line and a radius form a right triangle with the line connecting the external point to the center. If the radius is 5 and the distance from the center to the external point is 13, find the length of the tangent segment.

sub_topics.name: Properties of Chords
sub_topics.short_description: Apply theorems about chords including perpendicular bisectors and equidistant chords.

sub_topics.name: Perpendicular Bisectors of Chords
sub_topics.short_description: Apply the theorem that the perpendicular bisector of a chord passes through the center.
example_tasks: A chord is 24 cm long and is 5 cm from the center of the circle. Find the radius of the circle.
In circle O, chord AB = 16. If OD ⊥ AB at point D, and OD = 6, find the radius of the circle.
Prove that if a line through the center of a circle is perpendicular to a chord, it bisects the chord

sub_topics.name: Equidistant Chords
sub_topics.short_description: Apply the theorem that congruent chords are equidistant from the center.
example_tasks: Two chords in a circle are each 10 cm long. If one chord is 6 cm from the center, how far is the other chord from the center?
In circle O with radius 13, chord AB = 24. Find the distance from O to the chord.
Two chords are equidistant from the center of a circle. Prove that the chords are congruent.

sub_topics.name: Intersecting Chord Segments
sub_topics.short_description: Apply the theorem that products of chord segments are equal when chords intersect.
example_tasks: Two chords AB and CD intersect at point E. If AE = 4, EB = 6, and CE = 3, find ED.
Chords intersect inside a circle creating segments of lengths 5, 8, x, and 10. Find x.
Prove the theorem: If two chords intersect in the interior of a circle, then the product of the segments of one chord equals the product of the segments of the other chord

sub_topics.name: Arc Length and Sector Area
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate arc length and sector area using proportions and formulas.

sub_topics.name: Arc Length
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate the length of an arc given the central angle and radius.
example_tasks: Find the arc length of a circle with radius 9 cm and central angle 60°.
A circle has a radius of 15 inches. Find the length of an arc with a central angle of 120°.
An arc has length 8π feet and is part of a circle with radius 12 feet. Find the measure of the central angle in degrees.
