sub_topics.name: Area of a Sector
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate the area of a sector given the central angle and radius.
example_tasks: Find the area of a sector with radius 10 cm and central angle 72°.
A circle has a radius of 8 inches. Find the area of a sector with central angle 135°.
A sector has an area of 25π square meters and a radius of 10 meters. Find the measure of the central angle.

sub_topics.name: Area of a Segment
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate the area of a circular segment by subtracting triangle area from sector area.
example_tasks: Find the area of a segment formed by a 90° arc in a circle of radius 6 cm.
A chord divides a circle of radius 10 into two segments. If the chord subtends a central angle of 120°, find the area of the smaller segment.
In a circle with radius 8, a chord is 8 units from the center. Find the area of the smaller segment formed by the chord.

sub_topics.name: Surface Area and Volume of 3D Figures
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate surface area and volume for prisms, cylinders, pyramids, cones, and spheres.

sub_topics.name: Prisms and Cylinders
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate surface area and volume of prisms and cylinders using appropriate formulas.
example_tasks: Find the volume and surface area of a rectangular prism with dimensions 5 cm × 8 cm × 12 cm.
A cylinder has a radius of 4 inches and a height of 10 inches. Find its volume and total surface area.
A triangular prism has a right triangular base with legs 6 and 8, and height 15. Find the volume and surface area.

sub_topics.name: Pyramids and Cones
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate surface area and volume of pyramids and cones.
example_tasks: Find the volume of a square pyramid with base edge 10 cm and height 12 cm.
A cone has a radius of 5 feet and a slant height of 13 feet. Find the surface area and volume.
A pyramid has a rectangular base 8 by 6 meters and a height of 10 meters. Find the volume and the length of a lateral edge.

sub_topics.name: Spheres
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate surface area and volume of spheres using the formulas SA = 4πr² and V = (4/3)πr³.
example_tasks: Find the surface area and volume of a sphere with radius 9 cm.
A sphere has a surface area of 144π square inches. Find its radius and volume.
A hemisphere (half-sphere) has a radius of 6 feet. Find its total surface area including the base and its volume.

sub_topics.name: Composite 3D Figures
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate surface area and volume of figures composed of multiple 3D shapes.
example_tasks: A figure consists of a cylinder with radius 4 and height 10, topped with a cone of radius 4 and height 6. Find the total volume.
A capsule shape is formed by a cylinder of radius 3 cm and height 8 cm with hemispheres on each end. Find the total volume.
A building model consists of a rectangular prism base (20×30×40 feet) with a square pyramid roof (base 20×30, height 15 feet). Find the total volume.

grade_9_10.name: Coordinate Geometry
grade_9_10.short_description: Students analyze geometric figures using coordinates, apply formulas for distance and midpoint, and prove geometric relationships algebraically. This topic bridges algebra and geometry through the coordinate plane.

sub_topics.name: Distance and Midpoint
sub_topics.short_description: Apply distance and midpoint formulas to solve problems in the coordinate plane.

sub_topics.name: Distance Formula
sub_topics.short_description: Use the distance formula d = √[(x₂-x₁)² + (y₂-y₁)²] to find distances between points.
example_tasks: Find the distance between points A(2, 3) and B(8, 11).
Determine if triangle ABC with vertices A(-1, 2), B(3, 5), and C(6, 1) is isosceles by comparing side lengths.
Point P(x, 4) is equidistant from A(2, 1) and B(6, 7). Find the value of x.

sub_topics.name: Midpoint Formula
sub_topics.short_description: Use the midpoint formula M = ((x₁+x₂)/2, (y₁+y₂)/2) to find midpoints of segments.
example_tasks: Find the midpoint of the segment connecting A(4, 7) and B(10, 15).
The midpoint of segment CD is M(3, 5). If C is at (1, 2), find the coordinates of D.
Verify that the diagonals of quadrilateral ABCD with vertices A(0,0), B(4,2), C(6,6), D(2,4) bisect each other by finding their midpoints.

sub_topics.name: Partitioning Segments
sub_topics.short_description: Find coordinates of points that divide segments in given ratios.
example_tasks: Find the coordinates of point P that divides segment AB from A(2, 3) to B(8, 9) in the ratio 1:2.
Point M divides segment from (1, 4) to (7, 10) in the ratio 2:1. Find the coordinates of M.
A segment has endpoints A(-3, 5) and B(9, -3). Find the coordinates of the point that is 1/4 of the way from A to B.

sub_topics.name: Equations of Circles
sub_topics.short_description: Write and graph equations of circles in standard form and apply them to problems.

sub_topics.name: Standard Form of Circle Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Use the standard form (x-h)² + (y-k)² = r² to write and analyze circle equations.
example_tasks: Write the equation of a circle with center (3, -2) and radius 5.
Find the center and radius of the circle with equation (x+4)² + (y-1)² = 36.
Determine if the point (5, 6) lies on the circle with equation (x-2)² + (y-3)² = 25.

sub_topics.name: Graphing Circles
sub_topics.short_description: Graph circles from their equations and identify key features.
example_tasks: Graph the circle x² + y² = 16 and identify its center and radius.
Graph the circle (x-2)² + (y+3)² = 9.
A circle has its center at (-1, 4) and passes through the point (2, 8). Write its equation and graph it.

sub_topics.name: Completing the Square for Circles
sub_topics.short_description: Convert general form circle equations to standard form by completing the square.
example_tasks: Rewrite x² + y² + 6x - 4y - 12 = 0 in standard form by completing the square.
Find the center and radius of the circle x² + y² - 8x + 2y + 8 = 0.
Determine if x² + y² + 4x - 6y + 15 = 0 represents a circle, a point, or has no graph.

sub_topics.name: Slopes and Line Relationships
sub_topics.short_description: Use slopes to prove lines parallel or perpendicular and analyze geometric relationships.

sub_topics.name: Slope in Coordinate Geometry
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate slopes and apply them to classify geometric relationships.
example_tasks: Find the slope of the line passing through A(-2, 5) and B(4, -3).
Determine if points A(1, 2), B(4, 5), and C(7, 8) are collinear using slopes.
A quadrilateral has vertices A(0,0), B(4,1), C(5,5), D(1,4). Use slopes to determine if it is a parallelogram.

sub_topics.name: Proving Lines Parallel or Perpendicular
sub_topics.short_description: Use slope relationships to prove geometric properties of figures.
example_tasks: Prove that quadrilateral ABCD with vertices A(1,1), B(5,2), C(7,6), D(3,5) is a parallelogram.
Verify that triangle ABC with vertices A(0,0), B(6,3), C(3,9) is a right triangle.
Show that the diagonals of rectangle PQRS with vertices P(1,2), Q(7,4), R(8,8), S(2,6) are perpendicular or not by finding their slopes.

sub_topics.name: Perpendicular Bisectors in the Coordinate Plane
sub_topics.short_description: Find equations of perpendicular bisectors of segments using midpoints and perpendicular slopes.
example_tasks: Find the equation of the perpendicular bisector of the segment from A(2, 3) to B(6, 7).
Write the equation of the perpendicular bisector of the segment connecting (-3, 1) and (5, 9).
Find the point on the perpendicular bisector of segment AB where A(0,0) and B(8,6) that is equidistant from both endpoints and has a y-coordinate of 5.

sub_topics.name: Polygons in the Coordinate Plane
sub_topics.short_description: Classify and analyze polygons using coordinates, slopes, and distance formulas.

sub_topics.name: Classifying Triangles
sub_topics.short_description: Classify triangles as scalene, isosceles, equilateral, or right using coordinate geometry.
example_tasks: Classify triangle ABC with vertices A(0,0), B(3,4), C(6,0) by its sides and angles.
Determine if triangle DEF with D(-2,1), E(2,4), F(5,0) is isosceles, equilateral, or scalene.
A triangle has vertices at A(1,2), B(4,6), C(7,2). Show that it is an isosceles right triangle.

sub_topics.name: Classifying Quadrilaterals
sub_topics.short_description: Classify quadrilaterals as parallelograms, rectangles, rhombi, or squares using coordinate methods.
example_tasks: Classify quadrilateral ABCD with vertices A(1,1), B(4,2), C(5,5), D(2,4) as specifically as possible.
Prove that PQRS with P(0,0), Q(5,0), R(7,4), S(2,4) is a parallelogram but not a rectangle.
Determine if quadrilateral WXYZ with W(-3,0), X(0,4), Y(3,0), Z(0,-4) is a rhombus, square, or just a parallelogram.

sub_topics.name: Area of Polygons Using Coordinates
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate areas of polygons using coordinate formulas and decomposition methods.
example_tasks: Find the area of triangle ABC with vertices A(1,2), B(5,8), C(9,3) using the formula: Area = ½|x₁(y₂-y₃) + x₂(y₃-y₁) + x₃(y₁-y₂)|.
Calculate the area of quadrilateral PQRS with P(0,0), Q(6,2), R(8,8), S(2,6) by dividing it into triangles.
A polygon has vertices at (1,1), (4,1), (5,4), (2,5). Find its area.

sub_topics.name: Transformations in the Coordinate Plane
sub_topics.short_description: Perform and analyze transformations including translations, reflections, rotations, and dilations using coordinates.

sub_topics.name: Translations
sub_topics.short_description: Apply translation rules (x,y) → (x+a, y+b) to move figures in the coordinate plane.
example_tasks: Translate triangle ABC with vertices A(2,3), B(5,7), C(8,4) using the rule (x,y) → (x-3, y+2).
A figure is translated 4 units right and 5 units down. Write the translation rule and apply it to point P(-1,6).
Find the translation rule that maps A(3,5) to A'(-2,8).

sub_topics.name: Reflections
sub_topics.short_description: Reflect figures across the x-axis, y-axis, and other lines using coordinate rules.
example_tasks: Reflect point A(4,-3) across the x-axis, then across the y-axis, then across the line y=x.
Triangle PQR has vertices P(2,5), Q(6,8), R(9,3). Find the coordinates after reflection across the y-axis.
Reflect quadrilateral ABCD across the line y = x and state the coordinates of A'B'C'D'.

sub_topics.name: Rotations
sub_topics.short_description: Rotate figures 90°, 180°, and 270° about the origin using rotation rules.
example_tasks: Rotate point A(3,5) 90° counterclockwise about the origin.
Triangle ABC with vertices A(2,1), B(5,3), C(4,6) is rotated 180° about the origin. Find the new coordinates.
A square has vertices at (1,1), (4,1), (4,4), (1,4). Find the coordinates after a 270° counterclockwise rotation about the origin.

sub_topics.name: Dilations
sub_topics.short_description: Apply dilations with given scale factors centered at the origin or other points.
example_tasks: Dilate triangle DEF with vertices D(2,4), E(6,2), F(4,8) by a scale factor of 3 centered at the origin.
A figure is dilated by a scale factor of 1/2 centered at the origin. If point A is at (8,6), where is A'?
Dilate point P(4,6) by a scale factor of 2 centered at point C(1,2). Find the coordinates of P'.

sub_topics.name: Composition of Transformations
sub_topics.short_description: Perform sequences of transformations and determine single transformations equivalent to compositions.
example_tasks: Point A(3,5) is reflected across the x-axis, then translated 2 units left. Find the final coordinates.
Triangle ABC is rotated 90° clockwise about the origin, then reflected across the y-axis. Describe a single transformation that achieves the same result.
A figure undergoes the transformation (x,y) → (x+3, y-2) followed by (x,y) → (2x, 2y). Write a single rule for the composition.

grade_9_10.name: Statistics: Data Analysis
grade_9_10.short_description: Students interpret and analyze univariate and bivariate data using measures of center, spread, and various data displays. This topic develops statistical literacy and data interpretation skills.

sub_topics.name: Measures of Center and Spread
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate and interpret mean, median, mode, range, interquartile range, and standard deviation.

sub_topics.name: Mean, Median, and Mode
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate and compare measures of center for data sets.
example_tasks: Find the mean, median, and mode of the data set: 12, 15, 18, 15, 22, 19, 15, 24.
Test scores are: 78, 85, 92, 88, 76, 95, 100, 82. Which measure of center best represents the typical score? Explain.
A data set has a mean of 50 and contains the values 45, 52, 48, 55, and x. Find the value of x.

sub_topics.name: Range and Interquartile Range
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate range, quartiles, and interquartile range to measure data spread.
example_tasks: Find the range, Q1, Q3, and IQR for the data set: 5, 8, 12, 15, 18, 22, 25, 30, 35.
A box plot shows Q1 = 20, median = 28, Q3 = 35. Find the IQR.
Data set A has IQR = 10 and data set B has IQR = 25. Which data set has greater variability? Explain.

sub_topics.name: Standard Deviation and Variance
sub_topics.short_description: Understand and calculate standard deviation as a measure of spread around the mean.
example_tasks: Calculate the variance and standard deviation for the data set: 4, 8, 6, 10, 12.
Two data sets have the same mean but different standard deviations (5 vs. 15). What does this tell you about the data sets?
A data set has mean 50 and standard deviation 8. Approximately what percentage of values fall within one standard deviation of the mean if the data is approximately normal?

sub_topics.name: Identifying and Analyzing Outliers
sub_topics.short_description: Identify outliers using the 1.5 × IQR rule and analyze their effect on statistics.
example_tasks: For a data set with Q1 = 15 and Q3 = 35, determine if the value 70 is an outlier using the 1.5 × IQR rule.
Data set: 12, 14, 15, 16, 18, 20, 45. Identify any outliers and explain how removing them affects the mean and median.
Why might you choose to use the median instead of the mean when a data set contains outliers?

sub_topics.name: Data Displays and Distributions
sub_topics.short_description: Create and interpret various data displays including histograms, box plots, and dot plots.

sub_topics.name: Histograms
sub_topics.short_description: Create and interpret histograms to display frequency distributions.
example_tasks: Create a histogram for the following test scores grouped by 10s: 65, 72, 78, 85, 88, 90, 92, 95, 68, 75, 82, 88, 91, 94.
A histogram shows that most data falls in the 40-60 range with a long tail extending to 100. Describe the shape of the distribution.
Compare two histograms representing class test scores from two different teachers. What conclusions can you draw about the distributions?

sub_topics.name: Box Plots
sub_topics.short_description: Create and interpret box plots (box-and-whisker plots) to display five-number summaries.
example_tasks: Create a box plot for the data set: 15, 22, 25, 28, 30, 35, 38, 42, 45, 50, 55.
A box plot shows minimum = 10, Q1 = 20, median = 30, Q3 = 45, maximum = 60. What percentage of the data falls between 20 and 45?
Compare two box plots showing salary distributions for two companies. Which company has greater salary variability?

sub_topics.name: Dot Plots and Stem-and-Leaf Plots
sub_topics.short_description: Create and interpret dot plots and stem-and-leaf plots for small to medium data sets.
example_tasks: Create a dot plot for the ages: 12, 13, 13, 14, 14, 14, 15, 15, 16, 17.
Construct a stem-and-leaf plot for the data: 23, 27, 31, 34, 35, 38, 42, 45, 46, 48, 52.
From a stem-and-leaf plot, identify the median, mode, and range of the data.

sub_topics.name: Shapes of Distributions
sub_topics.short_description: Identify and describe distributions as symmetric, skewed left, skewed right, or uniform.
example_tasks: Describe the shape of a distribution where most values cluster on the left with a long tail extending right.
For a symmetric distribution, what is the relationship between mean and median?
A data set showing household incomes is skewed right. Explain why this makes sense in the real world.

sub_topics.name: Comparing Data Sets
sub_topics.short_description: Compare two or more data sets using measures of center, spread, and visual displays.

sub_topics.name: Comparing Center and Spread
sub_topics.short_description: Compare data sets using appropriate measures based on distribution shapes.
example_tasks: Class A has mean = 75, median = 78, IQR = 12. Class B has mean = 75, median = 75, IQR = 20. Compare the distributions.
Two data sets have the same median but different IQRs. What does this tell you about the data sets?
When comparing skewed distributions, why is it better to use median and IQR rather than mean and standard deviation?

sub_topics.name: Parallel Box Plots
sub_topics.short_description: Use parallel box plots to compare multiple distributions visually.
example_tasks: Create parallel box plots to compare test scores from three different classes with five-number summaries provided.
Two box plots compare response times for two websites. Website A shows less variability and a lower median. What conclusions can you draw?
Parallel box plots show movie ratings across four genres. Identify which genre has the greatest variability and which has the highest median rating.

sub_topics.name: Standardized Scores (z-scores)
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate and interpret z-scores to compare values from different distributions.
example_tasks: A student scores 85 on a test with mean 75 and standard deviation 8. Calculate and interpret the z-score.
Compare two test scores: Score A is 80 (mean=70, SD=5), Score B is 90 (mean=85, SD=10). Which is relatively better?
A value has a z-score of -2. What does this tell you about its position relative to the mean?

sub_topics.name: Bivariate Data and Scatter Plots
sub_topics.short_description: Analyze relationships between two quantitative variables using scatter plots and correlation.

sub_topics.name: Creating and Interpreting Scatter Plots
sub_topics.short_description: Create scatter plots and describe patterns including direction, form, and strength.
example_tasks: Create a scatter plot for the data pairs: (1,3), (2,5), (3,6), (4,8), (5,9). Describe the association.
A scatter plot shows hours studied vs. test scores. Describe what a positive association would indicate.
Identify whether the following scatter plots show positive, negative, or no association: (a) height vs. weight, (b) age of car vs. value, (c) shoe size vs. IQ.

sub_topics.name: Correlation
sub_topics.short_description: Understand correlation as a measure of linear association between two variables.
example_tasks: Estimate whether the correlation coefficient is close to -1, 0, or 1 for a scatter plot showing a strong positive linear pattern.
Two variables have a correlation of r = -0.85. Describe the relationship between the variables.
Explain why correlation does not imply causation using an example of two variables that are correlated but not causally related.

sub_topics.name: Lines of Best Fit
sub_topics.short_description: Draw and interpret trend lines for scatter plots and make predictions.
example_tasks: Draw a line of best fit for a scatter plot showing study hours vs. test scores. Estimate the test score for someone who studies 4 hours.
A line of best fit has equation y = 2.5x + 30. If x represents hours worked and y represents earnings, interpret the slope and y-intercept.
Use a trend line to predict the value of a car after 8 years if the line of best fit is y = -1500x + 20000, where x is years and y is value.

sub_topics.name: Residuals
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate and interpret residuals to assess the fit of a linear model.
example_tasks: A data point is at (3, 8) and the predicted value from the line of best fit is 7. Calculate the residual.
If most residuals are small and randomly scattered, what does this indicate about the linear model?
A residual plot shows a clear pattern rather than random scatter. What does this suggest about the appropriateness of a linear model?

sub_topics.name: Categorical Data and Two-Way Tables
sub_topics.short_description: Organize and analyze categorical data using two-way frequency tables and relative frequencies.

sub_topics.name: Two-Way Frequency Tables
sub_topics.short_description: Create and interpret two-way tables to display relationships between two categorical variables.
example_tasks: Create a two-way table for survey data: 30 males prefer dogs (20 prefer cats), 25 females prefer dogs (35 prefer cats).
From a two-way table showing grade level vs. sport preference, find the total number of students who prefer soccer.
A two-way table shows employment status by education level. Calculate the total number of people surveyed.

sub_topics.name: Relative Frequencies and Conditional Probabilities
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate joint, marginal, and conditional relative frequencies from two-way tables.
example_tasks: In a two-way table with 200 total respondents, 60 are females who prefer outdoor activities. Find the joint relative frequency.
Calculate the marginal relative frequency of males in a survey where 120 out of 300 respondents are male.
Given that a person prefers comedy movies, what is the conditional relative frequency that they are under 25 years old?

sub_topics.name: Association in Categorical Data
sub_topics.short_description: Determine if there is an association between two categorical variables using conditional distributions.
example_tasks: Compare the distribution of sport preferences for males vs. females. Is there evidence of an association between gender and sport preference?
A two-way table shows smoking status vs. lung disease. Calculate conditional percentages to determine if there appears to be an association.
If the conditional distributions are similar across categories, what does this suggest about the association between variables?

grade_9_10.name: Probability: Basic Concepts
grade_9_10.short_description: Students explore fundamental probability concepts including sample spaces, independent and conditional probability, and counting principles. This topic establishes foundations for statistical inference and decision-making.

sub_topics.name: Probability Fundamentals
sub_topics.short_description: Understand basic probability concepts, notation, and simple probability calculations.

sub_topics.name: Sample Space and Events
sub_topics.short_description: Identify sample spaces and events for probability experiments.
example_tasks: List the sample space for rolling a die and flipping a coin simultaneously.
A bag contains 3 red, 2 blue, and 5 green marbles. Describe the sample space and the event 'drawing a red marble.'
For the experiment of drawing two cards from a deck without replacement, how many outcomes are in the sample space?

sub_topics.name: Theoretical Probability
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate theoretical probabilities using the formula P(E) = (favorable outcomes)/(total outcomes).
example_tasks: What is the probability of rolling a 4 on a standard six-sided die?
A bag contains 5 red, 3 blue, and 2 yellow marbles. Find P(blue).
What is the probability of drawing a face card (Jack, Queen, or King) from a standard deck of 52 cards?

sub_topics.name: Experimental Probability
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate experimental probabilities from data and compare to theoretical probabilities.
example_tasks: A coin is flipped 100 times, landing on heads 47 times. Find the experimental probability of heads.
In 50 rolls of a die, a 6 appears 12 times. Compare the experimental probability to the theoretical probability.
A basketball player makes 45 out of 60 free throw attempts. Estimate the probability of making the next free throw.

sub_topics.name: Complementary Events
sub_topics.short_description: Use the complement rule P(not A) = 1 - P(A) to find probabilities.
example_tasks: If the probability of rain tomorrow is 0.35, what is the probability it will not rain?
The probability of winning a game is 0.15. Find the probability of not winning.
In a class, the probability that a randomly selected student plays a sport is 2/3. What is the probability that a student does not play a sport?

sub_topics.name: Compound Events
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate probabilities of compound events using addition and multiplication rules.

sub_topics.name: Addition Rule for Probability
sub_topics.short_description: Apply the addition rule for mutually exclusive and non-mutually exclusive events.
example_tasks: A card is drawn from a deck. Find P(heart or diamond).
What is the probability of rolling a 3 or a 5 on a six-sided die?
Find P(heart or king) when drawing from a standard deck. Are these events mutually exclusive?

sub_topics.name: Multiplication Rule for Independent Events
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate probabilities of independent events using P(A and B) = P(A) × P(B).
example_tasks: A coin is flipped and a die is rolled. Find the probability of getting heads and rolling a 4.
Two cards are drawn from a deck with replacement. Find the probability both are aces.
The probability of rain on Monday is 0.3 and on Tuesday is 0.4 (independent). Find the probability it rains both days.

sub_topics.name: Tree Diagrams and Probability
sub_topics.short_description: Use tree diagrams to organize and calculate probabilities for multi-stage experiments.
example_tasks: Create a tree diagram for flipping a coin twice. Find P(at least one head).
A bag contains 3 red and 2 blue marbles. Create a tree diagram for drawing two marbles without replacement and find P(both red).
Use a tree diagram to find the probability of getting exactly two heads when flipping a coin three times.

sub_topics.name: Area Models for Probability
sub_topics.short_description: Use area models and two-way tables to represent and calculate compound probabilities.
example_tasks: Create an area model for rolling two dice. Use it to find P(sum = 7).
Two spinners are used: one with sections 1, 2, 3 and one with sections A, B. Create an area model showing all outcomes.
Use an area model to find the probability of selecting a red marble from bag 1 and a blue marble from bag 2.

sub_topics.name: Conditional Probability
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate and interpret conditional probabilities and understand independence.

sub_topics.name: Understanding Conditional Probability
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate P(A|B) using the formula and interpret conditional probability in context.
example_tasks: In a class of 30 students, 12 are in band and 8 of those are also in chorus. Find P(chorus | band).
A card is drawn from a deck. Given that it is red, find the probability it is a diamond.
Of 100 people surveyed, 60 drink coffee and 40 of those also drink tea. Find P(tea | coffee).

sub_topics.name: Testing for Independence
sub_topics.short_description: Determine if two events are independent using the condition P(A|B) = P(A).
example_tasks: Are the events 'drawing a heart' and 'drawing a king' independent? Verify using probabilities.
If P(A) = 0.4, P(B) = 0.5, and P(A and B) = 0.2, are A and B independent?
A die is rolled. Are the events 'rolling an even number' and 'rolling a number greater than 3' independent?

sub_topics.name: Conditional Probability with Two-Way Tables
sub_topics.short_description: Use two-way tables to calculate and interpret conditional probabilities.
example_tasks: From a two-way table showing gender and handedness, find P(left-handed | female).
A table shows 200 students' lunch preferences by grade. Calculate P(prefers pizza | 10th grade).
Use conditional probabilities from a two-way table to determine if there is an association between two variables.

sub_topics.name: Counting Principles
sub_topics.short_description: Apply fundamental counting principle, permutations, and combinations to calculate probabilities.

sub_topics.name: Fundamental Counting Principle
sub_topics.short_description: Use multiplication to count outcomes when making a sequence of choices.
example_tasks: A restaurant offers 4 appetizers, 6 entrees, and 3 desserts. How many different three-course meals are possible?
How many different 3-digit codes can be formed using digits 0-9 if repetition is allowed?
A license plate has 2 letters followed by 4 digits. How many different plates are possible?

sub_topics.name: Permutations
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate permutations when order matters using factorial notation and formulas.
example_tasks: In how many ways can 5 books be arranged on a shelf?
How many different 4-letter arrangements can be made from the letters in 'MATH'?
Ten people compete in a race. In how many ways can gold, silver, and bronze medals be awarded?

sub_topics.name: Combinations
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate combinations when order does not matter using the combination formula.
example_tasks: A committee of 3 people is chosen from 10 people. How many different committees are possible?
From a deck of 52 cards, how many different 5-card hands can be dealt?
A pizza shop offers 8 toppings. How many different 3-topping pizzas can be ordered?

sub_topics.name: Using Counting Principles in Probability
sub_topics.short_description: Apply counting techniques to calculate probabilities for complex events.
example_tasks: Five cards are dealt from a deck. What is the probability all are hearts?
A committee of 4 is chosen from 6 men and 4 women. Find the probability the committee has exactly 2 women.
A password consists of 4 different digits. What is the probability it contains no odd digits?

sub_topics.name: Simulations and Expected Value
sub_topics.short_description: Design and conduct probability simulations and calculate expected values for decision-making.

sub_topics.name: Designing Probability Simulations
sub_topics.short_description: Design simulations using random number generators and physical devices to model probability situations.
example_tasks: Design a simulation to estimate the probability of getting at least 2 heads when flipping 3 coins.
Describe how to use a random number generator to simulate drawing marbles from a bag containing 3 red and 7 blue marbles.
Design a simulation for a basketball player with a 70% free throw success rate to estimate the probability of making at least 3 out of 5 shots.

sub_topics.name: Expected Value
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate expected value as the average outcome of a probability experiment over many trials.
example_tasks: A game costs $2 to play. You roll a die and win $5 if you roll a 6, otherwise you win nothing. Find the expected value.
A raffle sells 100 tickets for $5 each. The prize is $200. What is the expected value of buying one ticket?
An insurance company charges $500 for a policy. There is a 2% chance of a claim worth $20,000. Find the company's expected profit per policy.

sub_topics.name: Using Probability for Decision Making
sub_topics.short_description: Apply probability concepts and expected value to make informed decisions.
example_tasks: Two games are available: Game A has a 10% chance to win $50, Game B has a 25% chance to win $15. Which has a better expected value?
A company can choose Project A (60% success, $100K profit) or Project B (40% success, $180K profit). Which has higher expected value?
Based on weather probabilities, should a farmer plant crop A (needs sun) or crop B (tolerates rain)? Use expected values with given profit/loss data.

grade_9_10.name: Sequences and Series Introduction
grade_9_10.short_description: Students explore arithmetic and geometric sequences, write explicit and recursive formulas, and find sums of finite series. This topic introduces patterns and prepares students for advanced sequence and series work.

sub_topics.name: Arithmetic Sequences
sub_topics.short_description: Identify, extend, and write formulas for arithmetic sequences with constant differences.

sub_topics.name: Understanding Arithmetic Sequences
sub_topics.short_description: Identify arithmetic sequences and find common differences and terms.
example_tasks: Determine if the sequence 3, 7, 11, 15, 19 is arithmetic. If so, find the common difference.
Find the next three terms in the arithmetic sequence: 5, 9, 13, 17, ...
Is the sequence 2, 4, 8, 16, 32 arithmetic? Explain why or why not.

sub_topics.name: Explicit Formula for Arithmetic Sequences
sub_topics.short_description: Write and use the explicit formula aₙ = a₁ + (n-1)d for arithmetic sequences.
example_tasks: Write an explicit formula for the arithmetic sequence with first term 7 and common difference 4.
Find the 25th term of the arithmetic sequence: 12, 9, 6, 3, ...
An arithmetic sequence has a₁ = 5 and a₁₀ = 50. Find the common difference and write the explicit formula.

sub_topics.name: Recursive Formula for Arithmetic Sequences
sub_topics.short_description: Write and use recursive formulas in the form aₙ = aₙ₋₁ + d.
example_tasks: Write a recursive formula for the sequence: 8, 11, 14, 17, ...
Given a₁ = 3 and aₙ = aₙ₋₁ + 5, find the first 5 terms.
Convert the explicit formula aₙ = 2n + 1 to recursive form.

sub_topics.name: Applications of Arithmetic Sequences
sub_topics.short_description: Model real-world situations using arithmetic sequences.
example_tasks: A theater has 20 seats in the first row and each row has 3 more seats than the previous row. How many seats are in the 15th row?
A person saves $50 the first month and increases savings by $10 each month. How much will they save in the 12th month?
A subscription starts at $15/month and increases by $2/month. What will the monthly cost be in the 24th month?

sub_topics.name: Arithmetic Series
sub_topics.short_description: Find sums of finite arithmetic series using formulas.

sub_topics.name: Sum of Arithmetic Series
sub_topics.short_description: Use the formula Sₙ = n(a₁ + aₙ)/2 or Sₙ = n[2a₁ + (n-1)d]/2 to find sums.
example_tasks: Find the sum of the first 20 terms of the arithmetic sequence: 3, 7, 11, 15, ...
Calculate: 2 + 5 + 8 + 11 + ... (to 15 terms)
An arithmetic series has first term 10, last term 100, and 10 terms. Find the sum.

sub_topics.name: Summation Notation
sub_topics.short_description: Use sigma notation to represent and evaluate arithmetic series.
example_tasks: Evaluate: Σ(2i + 3) from i=1 to 10
Write the sum 5 + 8 + 11 + 14 + 17 + 20 using sigma notation
Find Σ(4n - 1) from n=1 to 25

sub_topics.name: Applications of Arithmetic Series
sub_topics.short_description: Solve real-world problems involving sums of arithmetic sequences.
example_tasks: A stack of logs has 25 logs in the bottom row, 24 in the next row, and so on, with 1 log on top. How many logs are in the stack?
An auditorium has 15 rows with 20 seats in the first row and each row has 2 more seats than the previous. Find the total seating capacity.
A person exercises 10 minutes the first day and increases by 5 minutes each day. How many total minutes will they exercise over 30 days?

sub_topics.name: Geometric Sequences (Review and Extension)
sub_topics.short_description: Review geometric sequences and extend understanding to more complex applications.

sub_topics.name: Geometric Sequence Formulas
sub_topics.short_description: Apply explicit formula aₙ = a₁ · r^(n-1) and recursive formula aₙ = aₙ₋₁ · r.
example_tasks: Find the 8th term of the geometric sequence: 2, 6, 18, 54, ...
Write both explicit and recursive formulas for the sequence: 80, 40, 20, 10, ...
A geometric sequence has a₁ = 5 and r = 3. Find a₁₀.

sub_topics.name: Geometric Means
sub_topics.short_description: Find geometric means between terms in a geometric sequence.
example_tasks: Find two geometric means between 3 and 81.
Insert three geometric means between 2 and 162.
The first term of a geometric sequence is 4 and the fourth term is 500. Find the two geometric means.

sub_topics.name: Growth and Decay Models
sub_topics.short_description: Model exponential growth and decay situations using geometric sequences.
example_tasks: A population of 1000 bacteria doubles every hour. Write a formula for the population after n hours and find the population after 8 hours.
A car worth $30,000 depreciates by 15% each year. What will it be worth after 5 years?
An investment of $5,000 grows at 6% per year. Find the value after 10 years using a geometric sequence.

sub_topics.name: Geometric Series
sub_topics.short_description: Find sums of finite geometric series using formulas.

sub_topics.name: Sum of Finite Geometric Series
sub_topics.short_description: Use the formula Sₙ = a₁(1 - rⁿ)/(1 - r) to find sums of geometric series.
example_tasks: Find the sum of the first 8 terms of the geometric series: 3 + 6 + 12 + 24 + ...
Calculate: 2 + 6 + 18 + 54 + ... (to 10 terms)
Find Σ(2 · 3^(i-1)) from i=1 to 7

sub_topics.name: Applications of Geometric Series
sub_topics.short_description: Apply geometric series to solve financial and real-world problems.
example_tasks: A ball is dropped from 100 feet and bounces to 80% of its previous height each time. Find the total vertical distance traveled after 5 bounces.
An investment pays $1000 the first year and increases by 5% each year. What is the total amount paid over 10 years?
A chain letter asks each person to send it to 3 friends. If you start the chain, how many people will receive it by the 6th generation (including you)?

sub_topics.name: Comparing Arithmetic and Geometric Sequences
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguish between arithmetic and geometric patterns and choose appropriate models.
example_tasks: Identify whether each sequence is arithmetic, geometric, or neither: (a) 2, 5, 8, 11, (b) 2, 6, 18, 54, (c) 1, 4, 9, 16
Which grows faster over 20 terms: an arithmetic sequence with a₁ = 10 and d = 5, or a geometric sequence with a₁ = 10 and r = 1.2?
A savings plan offers two options: (A) $100 first month, increasing $10 monthly, or (B) $50 first month, increasing 15% monthly. Which is better over 12 months?

grade_11_12.name: Advanced Polynomial Functions
grade_11_12.short_description: Students analyze higher-degree polynomial functions, rational functions, and complex zeros. This topic extends polynomial understanding to include division, graphing, and the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra.

sub_topics.name: Advanced Polynomial Division
sub_topics.short_description: Apply polynomial division techniques and theorems to analyze polynomial functions.

sub_topics.name: Polynomial Division Algorithm
sub_topics.short_description: Apply the division algorithm: P(x) = D(x)·Q(x) + R(x) where degree of R < degree of D.
example_tasks: Divide 2x⁴ - 3x³ + x² - 5x + 7 by x² - 2x + 1 and express in the form P(x) = D(x)·Q(x) + R(x).
Use long division to divide x⁵ + 2x³ - 4x + 3 by x² + x - 1.
If P(x) = (x - 3)(x² + 2x - 5) + 7, identify the divisor, quotient, and remainder.

sub_topics.name: Remainder and Factor Theorems Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Use theorems to find remainders, determine factors, and solve polynomial equations.
example_tasks: Without dividing, find the remainder when P(x) = 2x³ - 5x² + 3x - 8 is divided by (x - 4).
Determine if (2x + 3) is a factor of 4x³ + 6x² - 5x - 12 using the Factor Theorem.
Find all values of k such that (x + 2) is a factor of x³ + kx² - 5x + 6.

sub_topics.name: Rational Root Theorem
sub_topics.short_description: Apply the Rational Root Theorem to identify possible rational zeros of polynomials.
example_tasks: List all possible rational zeros of P(x) = 2x³ - 5x² + 3x - 6.
Use the Rational Root Theorem to find all rational zeros of f(x) = 3x⁴ - 10x³ + 3x² + 10x - 4.
Explain why x = 1/3 could be a rational zero of 6x⁴ - 5x² + 2x - 1 according to the Rational Root Theorem.

sub_topics.name: Graphing Polynomial Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Analyze and sketch graphs of polynomial functions using zeros, multiplicity, and end behavior.

sub_topics.name: Zeros and Multiplicity
sub_topics.short_description: Determine how multiplicity affects the graph's behavior at x-intercepts.
example_tasks: Sketch f(x) = (x - 2)²(x + 1)³ and describe the behavior at each zero.
If a polynomial has a zero of multiplicity 3 at x = -2, what does the graph do at x = -2?
Find a polynomial function of degree 4 with zeros at x = -1 (multiplicity 2) and x = 3 (multiplicity 2).

sub_topics.name: End Behavior Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Determine end behavior based on degree and leading coefficient.
example_tasks: Describe the end behavior of f(x) = -2x⁵ + 3x³ - x + 5 as x → ±∞.
Match each polynomial with its end behavior: (a) f(x) = x⁴ - 3x², (b) g(x) = -x³ + 2x, (c) h(x) = 2x⁵ + x².
If a polynomial has even degree and negative leading coefficient, describe its end behavior.

sub_topics.name: Turning Points and Local Extrema
sub_topics.short_description: Understand that a polynomial of degree n has at most n-1 turning points.
example_tasks: What is the maximum number of turning points for a polynomial of degree 5?
Sketch a polynomial of degree 4 that has exactly 3 turning points.
Can a cubic polynomial have 4 turning points? Explain why or why not.

sub_topics.name: Comprehensive Polynomial Graphing
sub_topics.short_description: Combine all features to sketch accurate graphs of polynomial functions.
example_tasks: Sketch f(x) = x³ - 4x² + x + 6 by finding zeros, end behavior, and testing values between zeros.
Graph g(x) = -x⁴ + 4x³ - 4x² and identify all zeros, turning points, and intervals of increase/decrease.
Given the polynomial f(x) = (x + 2)(x - 1)²(x - 4), sketch the graph and identify key features.

sub_topics.name: Complex Zeros of Polynomials
sub_topics.short_description: Apply the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra and work with complex conjugate pairs.

sub_topics.name: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra
sub_topics.short_description: Understand that a polynomial of degree n has exactly n zeros (counting multiplicity) in the complex number system.
example_tasks: How many zeros (including complex) does f(x) = 2x⁵ - 3x⁴ + x - 7 have?
A polynomial has degree 6. If it has 3 real zeros, how many complex zeros must it have?
Explain why x² + 1 has no real zeros but has two complex zeros.

sub_topics.name: Complex Conjugate Pairs
sub_topics.short_description: Apply the theorem that complex zeros of polynomials with real coefficients occur in conjugate pairs.
example_tasks: If 2 + 3i is a zero of a polynomial with real coefficients, what is another zero?
A polynomial with real coefficients has zeros 3, -1, and 2 - i. What is another zero and what is the minimum degree?
Find a polynomial of degree 4 with real coefficients that has zeros 1, -2, and 3i.

sub_topics.name: Factoring Polynomials with Complex Zeros
sub_topics.short_description: Factor polynomials completely over the complex numbers.
example_tasks: Factor x⁴ - 1 completely over the complex numbers.
Given that 1 + 2i is a zero of f(x) = x³ - 3x² + 7x - 5, find all zeros and write f(x) in factored form.
Factor completely: x⁴ + 4x² + 4

sub_topics.name: Writing Polynomials from Given Zeros
sub_topics.short_description: Construct polynomial functions given zeros and additional conditions.
example_tasks: Write a polynomial function of least degree with zeros -2, 3, and 1 + i.
Find a polynomial of degree 4 with real coefficients, zeros at 2 (multiplicity 2) and i, and f(0) = 8.
A polynomial has zeros -1, 3 - 2i, and passes through (0, 20). Find the polynomial.

sub_topics.name: Rational Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Analyze and graph rational functions including asymptotes, holes, and domain restrictions.

sub_topics.name: Domain of Rational Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Determine domain by finding values that make the denominator zero.
example_tasks: Find the domain of f(x) = (x + 3)/(x² - 4).
State the domain of g(x) = (2x - 1)/(x² + 5x + 6).
For h(x) = (x² - 9)/(x - 3), find the domain and explain why x ≠ 3.

sub_topics.name: Asymptotes of Rational Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Find vertical, horizontal, and oblique asymptotes using limits and degree comparison.
example_tasks: Find all asymptotes of f(x) = (2x² + 3x - 5)/(x² - 4).
Determine the horizontal asymptote of g(x) = (3x³ - 2x)/(x³ + 4x² - 1).
Find vertical and oblique asymptotes of h(x) = (x² + 2x - 3)/(x - 1).

sub_topics.name: Holes in Rational Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Identify holes (removable discontinuities) by finding common factors in numerator and denominator.
example_tasks: Find any holes in f(x) = (x² - 4)/(x² - x - 2).
Does g(x) = (x² - 9)/(x + 3) have a hole or vertical asymptote at x = -3? Find the coordinates of any hole.
Simplify h(x) = (2x² + 5x - 3)/(x² + 4x + 3) and identify any holes.

sub_topics.name: Graphing Rational Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Sketch graphs of rational functions using asymptotes, holes, intercepts, and sign analysis.
example_tasks: Sketch f(x) = (x + 2)/(x - 3) showing all asymptotes and intercepts.
Graph g(x) = (x² - 1)/(x² - 4) and identify all key features.
Sketch h(x) = (2x² + x - 3)/(x² - 1), showing asymptotes, holes, and intercepts.

sub_topics.name: Solving Rational Inequalities
sub_topics.short_description: Solve inequalities involving rational expressions using sign analysis and test points.
example_tasks: Solve: (x² - 4)/(x - 1) ≤ 0
Solve: (2x + 1)/(x² - 9) ≥ 0 and express the solution in interval notation.

sub_topics.name: Applications of Polynomial and Rational Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Model real-world situations using polynomial and rational functions.

sub_topics.name: Optimization with Polynomials
sub_topics.short_description: Use polynomial functions to model and solve optimization problems.
example_tasks: A box is made from a 20×30 inch sheet by cutting squares from corners. Express volume as a function of cut size and find dimensions for maximum volume.
A farmer has 1000 feet of fence. Express the area of a rectangular enclosure as a function of width and find maximum area.
A company's profit is modeled by P(x) = -2x³ + 60x² - 200x + 500. Find the production level that maximizes profit.

sub_topics.name: Modeling with Rational Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Apply rational functions to model average cost, concentration, and other real-world scenarios.
example_tasks: Average cost per unit is C(x) = (500 + 2x)/x where x is units produced. Find average cost for 100 units and analyze as x increases.
The concentration of a drug in the bloodstream is C(t) = (5t)/(t² + 1) mg/L after t hours. Find maximum concentration and when it occurs.
A car's fuel efficiency is E(v) = (20v)/(v + 30) mpg at speed v mph. Find the most efficient speed between 30-70 mph.

sub_topics.name: Work and Rate Problems
sub_topics.short_description: Use rational equations to model combined work rates and time problems.
example_tasks: Pipe A fills a pool in 4 hours, Pipe B in 6 hours, Pipe C drains it in 8 hours. How long to fill with all three running?
Working together, two machines complete a job in 3 hours. Alone, one takes 2 hours longer than the other. How long does each take alone?
A boat travels 30 miles upstream and 30 miles back in 5 hours total. If the current is 2 mph, find the boat's speed in still water.

grade_11_12.name: Exponential and Logarithmic Functions
grade_11_12.short_description: Students analyze exponential and logarithmic functions, their properties, graphs, and applications. This topic develops understanding of inverse relationships and logarithmic properties essential for calculus and real-world modeling.

sub_topics.name: Advanced Exponential Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Analyze exponential functions including the natural base e and continuous growth models.

sub_topics.name: The Natural Exponential Function
sub_topics.short_description: Work with the natural base e ≈ 2.71828 and the function f(x) = eˣ.
example_tasks: Evaluate e², e⁻¹, and e⁰ using a calculator.
Graph f(x) = eˣ and compare it to g(x) = 2ˣ and h(x) = 3ˣ.
Simplify: e^(2x) · e^(3x) and (e^x)³

sub_topics.name: Continuous Growth and Decay
sub_topics.short_description: Apply the continuous compound interest formula A = Pe^(rt) and continuous growth models.
example_tasks: An investment of $5,000 earns 4% interest compounded continuously. Find the value after 10 years.
A radioactive substance decays continuously at 5% per year. If there are initially 100 grams, write a function for the amount after t years.
Compare $1,000 invested at 6% compounded quarterly versus continuously over 20 years.

sub_topics.name: Solving Exponential Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Solve exponential equations using common bases and introducing logarithms.
example_tasks: Solve: 2^x · 4^(x+1) = 8³

sub_topics.name: Exponential Modeling
sub_topics.short_description: Model population growth, radioactive decay, and other phenomena using exponential functions.
example_tasks: A population grows from 10,000 to 15,000 in 5 years. Assuming exponential growth, find the growth rate and predict the population in 10 years.
Carbon-14 has a half-life of 5,730 years. Write an exponential decay function for a sample starting with 100 grams.
A car depreciates exponentially, losing 15% of its value each year. If it costs $28,000 new, write a function for its value and find when it's worth $10,000.

sub_topics.name: Logarithmic Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Understand logarithms as inverses of exponential functions and work with common and natural logarithms.

sub_topics.name: Definition of Logarithms
sub_topics.short_description: Understand that y = log_b(x) means b^y = x and convert between forms.
example_tasks: Convert to logarithmic form: 2⁵ = 32
Convert to exponential form: log₃(81) = 4
Evaluate: log₂(64), log₁₀(1000), log₅(1)

sub_topics.name: Common and Natural Logarithms
sub_topics.short_description: Work with common logarithms (log = log₁₀) and natural logarithms (ln = log_e).
example_tasks: Evaluate using a calculator: log(100), log(50), ln(e³)
Simplify: ln(e⁵), log(10⁷), ln(1)
If ln(x) = 3, find x.

sub_topics.name: Properties of Logarithms
sub_topics.short_description: Apply product, quotient, and power properties of logarithms.
example_tasks: Expand using logarithm properties: log(x³y²/z)
Condense to a single logarithm: 3ln(x) + 2ln(y) - ln(z)
Simplify: log₂(8) + log₂(4) - log₂(16)

sub_topics.name: Graphing Logarithmic Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Graph logarithmic functions and identify domain, range, asymptotes, and key features.
example_tasks: Graph f(x) = log₂(x) and identify domain, range, and vertical asymptote.
Graph g(x) = ln(x - 3) + 2 by applying transformations to f(x) = ln(x).
Compare the graphs of y = log(x) and y = ln(x). How are they similar and different?

sub_topics.name: Solving Logarithmic and Exponential Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Solve equations involving logarithms and exponentials using properties and inverse relationships.

sub_topics.name: Solving Logarithmic Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Solve equations containing logarithms by converting to exponential form or using properties.
example_tasks: Solve: log₂(x) = 5
Solve: log(x + 3) = 2
Solve: ln(2x - 1) = 3

sub_topics.name: Using Logarithms to Solve Exponential Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Apply logarithms to solve exponential equations that cannot be solved by common bases.
example_tasks: Solve: 3ˣ = 20 (use logarithms)
Solve: e^(0.05t) = 3

sub_topics.name: Equations with Multiple Logarithms
sub_topics.short_description: Solve equations with multiple logarithmic terms using properties and checking solutions.
example_tasks: Solve: log(x) + log(x - 3) = 1
Solve: ln(x + 2) - ln(x) = 1
Solve: log₂(x + 3) + log₂(x - 3) = 4 and check for extraneous solutions.

sub_topics.name: Change of Base Formula
sub_topics.short_description: Use the change of base formula log_b(x) = log(x)/log(b) to evaluate and solve logarithms with any base.
example_tasks: Evaluate log₅(30) using the change of base formula and a calculator.
Solve: log₃(x) = 2.5 using change of base.
Express log₇(x) in terms of natural logarithms.

sub_topics.name: Applications of Exponential and Logarithmic Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Apply exponential and logarithmic models to finance, science, and real-world problems.

sub_topics.name: Compound Interest and Finance
sub_topics.short_description: Use compound interest formulas including continuous compounding to solve financial problems.
example_tasks: How long will it take $2,000 to grow to $5,000 at 6% interest compounded monthly?
Compare investments: $10,000 at 5% compounded quarterly vs. 4.9% compounded continuously over 15 years.
What interest rate compounded continuously is needed to double an investment in 10 years?

sub_topics.name: Population Growth Models
sub_topics.short_description: Model population growth using exponential functions and solve related problems.
example_tasks: A city's population grows from 50,000 to 65,000 in 8 years. Assuming exponential growth, predict the population in 20 years.
A bacteria culture doubles every 3 hours. If there are 1,000 bacteria initially, how many will there be after 24 hours?
When will a population of 100,000 growing at 2.5% per year reach 150,000?

sub_topics.name: Half-Life and Radioactive Decay
sub_topics.short_description: Apply exponential decay models to half-life problems in chemistry and physics.
example_tasks: Plutonium-239 has a half-life of 24,000 years. How much of a 100-gram sample remains after 72,000 years?
A radioactive substance decays to 40% of its original amount in 10 years. Find its half-life.
If 20% of a radioactive substance remains after 100 years, find the decay rate k in the model A = A₀e^(kt).

sub_topics.name: Logarithmic Scales (pH, Richter, Decibels)
sub_topics.short_description: Work with logarithmic scales used in science including pH, earthquake magnitude, and sound intensity.
example_tasks: The pH of a solution is -log[H⁺]. If [H⁺] = 1.5 × 10⁻⁴, find the pH.
An earthquake measures 6.5 on the Richter scale. Another measures 7.5. How many times more intense is the second?
Sound intensity is measured in decibels: dB = 10log(I/I₀). If one sound is 60 dB and another is 80 dB, how many times more intense is the louder sound?

sub_topics.name: Newton's Law of Cooling
sub_topics.short_description: Apply exponential models to temperature change and cooling/heating problems.
example_tasks: A cup of coffee at 95°C is in a room at 20°C. After 5 minutes, it's 70°C. Use Newton's Law T(t) = Tₐ + (T₀ - Tₐ)e^(kt) to find when it reaches 40°C.
A turkey at 35°F is placed in a 350°F oven. After 30 minutes, the turkey is 75°F. When will it reach 165°F?
The temperature of an object cooling follows T(t) = 20 + 80e^(-0.1t). What is the room temperature and initial temperature of the object?

sub_topics.name: Inverse Relationship of Exponential and Logarithmic Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Understand and apply the inverse relationship between exponential and logarithmic functions.

sub_topics.name: Inverse Function Properties
sub_topics.short_description: Apply the properties that b^(log_b(x)) = x and log_b(b^x) = x.
example_tasks: Simplify: 10^(log(7))
Simplify: ln(e^(3x))
Simplify: log₂(2^(x+5))

sub_topics.name: Graphical Relationship
sub_topics.short_description: Understand that exponential and logarithmic functions are reflections across y = x.
example_tasks: Graph f(x) = 2^x and g(x) = log₂(x) on the same axes. Describe their relationship.
If (3, 8) is on the graph of f(x) = 2^x, what point must be on g(x) = log₂(x)?
Sketch y = eˣ and y = ln(x) and identify how they are related by the line y = x.

sub_topics.name: Composition of Inverse Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Verify inverse relationships using function composition.
example_tasks: Verify that f(x) = 3^x and g(x) = log₃(x) are inverses by showing f(g(x)) = x and g(f(x)) = x.
If f(x) = e^(2x) and g(x) = (1/2)ln(x), verify these are inverse functions.
Find the inverse of h(x) = ln(x - 3) + 2 and verify your answer.

grade_11_12.name: Trigonometric Functions
grade_11_12.short_description: Students extend trigonometry beyond right triangles using the unit circle, analyze trigonometric functions and their graphs, and apply trigonometric identities. This topic provides essential foundations for calculus and advanced mathematics.

sub_topics.name: Unit Circle and Radian Measure
sub_topics.short_description: Work with angles in radian measure and apply the unit circle to define trigonometric functions.

sub_topics.name: Radian and Degree Measure
sub_topics.short_description: Convert between degrees and radians using the relationship 180° = π radians.
example_tasks: Convert 135° to radians.
Convert 5π/6 radians to degrees.
Convert -210° to radians in terms of π.

sub_topics.name: The Unit Circle
sub_topics.short_description: Identify coordinates on the unit circle for special angles and understand that cos(θ) = x and sin(θ) = y.
example_tasks: Find the coordinates of the point on the unit circle corresponding to θ = π/3.
If a point on the unit circle has coordinates (-1/2, √3/2), what is the angle in radians?
State the coordinates for angles 0, π/6, π/4, π/3, π/2, π on the unit circle.

sub_topics.name: Reference Angles
sub_topics.short_description: Find reference angles and use them to evaluate trigonometric functions for any angle.
example_tasks: Find the reference angle for 150°.
Find the reference angle for 7π/4 radians.
Use reference angles to find sin(240°) and cos(5π/6).

sub_topics.name: Trigonometric Functions of Any Angle
sub_topics.short_description: Evaluate sine, cosine, and tangent for angles in any quadrant using the unit circle.
example_tasks: Evaluate sin(3π/4), cos(3π/4), and tan(3π/4).
Find the exact values of sin(300°), cos(300°), and tan(300°).
If sin(θ) = -3/5 and θ is in Quadrant III, find cos(θ) and tan(θ).

sub_topics.name: Graphs of Trigonometric Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Analyze and graph sine, cosine, tangent, and their transformations.

sub_topics.name: Graphs of Sine and Cosine
sub_topics.short_description: Graph y = sin(x) and y = cos(x) and identify period, amplitude, and key features.
example_tasks: Sketch one complete period of y = sin(x) and identify the amplitude, period, and zeros.
Graph y = cos(x) for -2π ≤ x ≤ 2π and identify maximum and minimum values.
Compare the graphs of y = sin(x) and y = cos(x). How are they related?

sub_topics.name: Amplitude, Period, and Phase Shift
sub_topics.short_description: Analyze transformations of the form y = A·sin(B(x - C)) + D and y = A·cos(B(x - C)) + D.
example_tasks: Find the amplitude and period of y = 3sin(2x).
Graph y = 2cos(x - π/2) + 1 and identify amplitude, period, phase shift, and vertical shift.
Write an equation for a sine function with amplitude 4, period π, and phase shift π/4 to the right.

sub_topics.name: Graph of Tangent Function
sub_topics.short_description: Graph y = tan(x) and identify period, asymptotes, and key features.
example_tasks: Sketch one period of y = tan(x) and identify the vertical asymptotes.
Find the period of y = tan(2x) and sketch its graph.
Graph y = tan(x - π/4) and identify the phase shift and asymptotes.

sub_topics.name: Graphs of Cosecant, Secant, and Cotangent
sub_topics.short_description: Graph reciprocal trigonometric functions and identify asymptotes and relationships to sine, cosine, and tangent.
example_tasks: Sketch y = csc(x) by first graphing y = sin(x) and identifying where csc(x) is undefined.
Graph y = sec(x) and identify its period and asymptotes.
Graph y = 2sec(x) and describe how it relates to y = 2cos(x).

sub_topics.name: Fundamental Trigonometric Identities
sub_topics.short_description: Apply Pythagorean, reciprocal, quotient, and co-function identities to simplify expressions.

sub_topics.name: Pythagorean Identities
sub_topics.short_description: Apply sin²(θ) + cos²(θ) = 1 and related identities to simplify expressions.
example_tasks: If sin(θ) = 3/5 and θ is in Quadrant II, find cos(θ) using a Pythagorean identity.
Simplify: 1 - cos²(x)
Prove that tan²(x) + 1 = sec²(x) using Pythagorean identities.

sub_topics.name: Reciprocal and Quotient Identities
sub_topics.short_description: Use reciprocal relationships and tan(θ) = sin(θ)/cos(θ) to simplify expressions.
example_tasks: Express tan(x) + cot(x) in terms of sin(x) and cos(x), then simplify.
Simplify: sec(x)·sin(x)
Rewrite (1 + tan²(x))/sec²(x) as a single number.

sub_topics.name: Co-function Identities
sub_topics.short_description: Apply relationships such as sin(90° - θ) = cos(θ) to evaluate and simplify.
example_tasks: Evaluate sin(25°) using a co-function of cosine.
Simplify: cos(π/2 - x)
If tan(θ) = cot(40°), find θ.

sub_topics.name: Simplifying Trigonometric Expressions
sub_topics.short_description: Combine multiple identities to simplify complex trigonometric expressions.
example_tasks: Simplify: (sin(x) + cos(x))² + (sin(x) - cos(x))²
Simplify: (1 - sin²(x))(1 + tan²(x))
Prove that (sec(x) - tan(x))(sec(x) + tan(x)) = 1

sub_topics.name: Inverse Trigonometric Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Understand inverse trigonometric functions, their domains and ranges, and use them to find angles.

sub_topics.name: Inverse Sine, Cosine, and Tangent
sub_topics.short_description: Evaluate arcsin, arccos, and arctan and understand their restricted domains and ranges.
example_tasks: Evaluate arcsin(1/2) in radians.
Find arccos(-√2/2) in degrees.
Evaluate tan⁻¹(√3) and state the answer in both degrees and radians.

sub_topics.name: Compositions with Inverse Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Simplify compositions involving trigonometric and inverse trigonometric functions.
example_tasks: Simplify: sin(arcsin(0.6))
Evaluate: cos(arctan(3/4))
Simplify: tan(arccos(x))

sub_topics.name: Using Inverse Functions to Solve Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Apply inverse trigonometric functions to solve trigonometric equations.
example_tasks: Solve for θ in [0, π/2]: sin(θ) = 0.75
Solve: 2cos(x) = √3 for x in [0, 2π]
Find all solutions in [0°, 360°): tan(x) = -1

sub_topics.name: Solving Trigonometric Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Solve trigonometric equations using identities, factoring, and algebraic techniques.

sub_topics.name: Basic Trigonometric Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Solve equations involving a single trigonometric function.
example_tasks: Solve sin(x) = 1/2 for x in [0, 2π].
Solve 2cos(x) + 1 = 0 for x in [0°, 360°).
Find all solutions to tan(x) = 1 in the interval [-π, π].

sub_topics.name: Solving by Factoring
sub_topics.short_description: Solve trigonometric equations by factoring and applying the zero product property.
example_tasks: Solve: 2sin²(x) - sin(x) = 0 for x in [0, 2π].
Solve: cos²(x) = cos(x) for x in [0°, 360°).
Solve: tan(x)sin(x) - tan(x) = 0 in [0, 2π].

sub_topics.name: Equations in Quadratic Form
sub_topics.short_description: Solve equations that can be written in quadratic form using substitution.
example_tasks: Solve: 2cos²(x) + 3cos(x) - 2 = 0 for x in [0, 2π].
Solve: sin²(x) - 5sin(x) + 6 = 0 for x in [0°, 360°).
Solve: 4sin²(x) - 4sin(x) + 1 = 0 in [0, 2π].

sub_topics.name: Equations with Multiple Angles
sub_topics.short_description: Solve equations involving expressions like sin(2x) or cos(3x).
example_tasks: Solve: sin(2x) = √3/2 for x in [0, 2π].
Solve: cos(3x) = 1 for x in [0, π].
Solve: 2sin(x/2) = 1 for x in [0, 4π].

grade_11_12.name: Trigonometric Applications and Identities
grade_11_12.short_description: Students apply advanced trigonometric identities including sum/difference, double-angle, and half-angle formulas, and solve applications involving the Law of Sines and Law of Cosines. This topic extends trigonometry to non-right triangles and complex identities.

sub_topics.name: Sum and Difference Identities
sub_topics.short_description: Apply formulas for sin(A ± B), cos(A ± B), and tan(A ± B) to evaluate and prove identities.

sub_topics.name: Sum and Difference for Sine and Cosine
sub_topics.short_description: Use sin(A ± B) and cos(A ± B) formulas to find exact values and simplify expressions.
example_tasks: Find the exact value of sin(75°) using sin(45° + 30°).
Evaluate cos(π/12) using the difference formula.
Simplify: sin(x + π/2)

sub_topics.name: Sum and Difference for Tangent
sub_topics.short_description: Apply tan(A ± B) = (tan A ± tan B)/(1 ∓ tan A tan B) to evaluate and simplify.
example_tasks: Find the exact value of tan(105°) using tan(60° + 45°).
Simplify: tan(x - π/4)
If tan(A) = 2 and tan(B) = 3, find tan(A + B).

sub_topics.name: Proving Identities with Sum and Difference Formulas
sub_topics.short_description: Use sum and difference identities to prove more complex trigonometric identities.
example_tasks: Prove that sin(x + y) + sin(x - y) = 2sin(x)cos(y).
Prove: cos(A + B)cos(A - B) = cos²(A) - sin²(B)
Verify the identity: tan(π/4 + x) = (1 + tan(x))/(1 - tan(x))

sub_topics.name: Double-Angle and Half-Angle Identities
sub_topics.short_description: Apply double-angle and half-angle formulas to simplify expressions and solve equations.

sub_topics.name: Double-Angle Formulas
sub_topics.short_description: Use sin(2A), cos(2A), and tan(2A) formulas in various forms.
example_tasks: If sin(θ) = 3/5 and θ is in Quadrant I, find sin(2θ), cos(2θ), and tan(2θ).
Simplify: 2sin(x)cos(x)
Express cos(4x) in terms of cos(2x) using double-angle formulas.

sub_topics.name: Half-Angle Formulas
sub_topics.short_description: Apply half-angle formulas to find exact values and simplify expressions.
example_tasks: Find the exact value of sin(15°) using a half-angle formula.
If cos(θ) = -4/5 and π/2 < θ < π, find sin(θ/2).
Simplify: √[(1 - cos(x))/2]

sub_topics.name: Power-Reducing Formulas
sub_topics.short_description: Use power-reducing formulas to rewrite expressions with lower powers of sine and cosine.
example_tasks: Express sin²(x) in terms of cos(2x).
Rewrite cos⁴(x) without exponents greater than 1.
Simplify: sin²(x)cos²(x) using power-reducing formulas.

sub_topics.name: Solving Equations with Double and Half Angles
sub_topics.short_description: Solve trigonometric equations involving double-angle and half-angle expressions.
example_tasks: Solve: sin(2x) = cos(x) for x in [0, 2π].
Solve: cos(2x) + cos(x) = 0 for x in [0, 2π].
Solve: sin(x/2) = 1/2 for x in [0, 4π].

sub_topics.name: Product-to-Sum and Sum-to-Product Formulas
sub_topics.short_description: Convert between products and sums of trigonometric functions using specialized identities.

sub_topics.name: Product-to-Sum Formulas
sub_topics.short_description: Convert products like sin(A)cos(B) to sums of sines and cosines.
example_tasks: Express sin(5x)cos(3x) as a sum.
Rewrite cos(4θ)cos(2θ) as a sum of cosines.
Simplify: 2sin(7x)sin(3x)

sub_topics.name: Sum-to-Product Formulas
sub_topics.short_description: Convert sums like sin(A) + sin(B) to products.
example_tasks: Express sin(5x) + sin(3x) as a product.
Rewrite cos(7θ) - cos(3θ) as a product.
Prove: (sin(A) + sin(B))/(cos(A) + cos(B)) = tan((A+B)/2)

sub_topics.name: Applications of Product and Sum Formulas
sub_topics.short_description: Use these formulas to solve equations and simplify complex expressions.
example_tasks: Solve: sin(3x) + sin(x) = 0 for x in [0, 2π].
Simplify: (sin(5x) - sin(x))/(cos(5x) - cos(x))
Verify: sin(A) + sin(B) + sin(C) = 4cos(A/2)cos(B/2)cos(C/2) when A + B + C = π

sub_topics.name: Law of Sines
sub_topics.short_description: Apply the Law of Sines to solve oblique (non-right) triangles and analyze ambiguous cases.

sub_topics.name: Applying the Law of Sines
sub_topics.short_description: Use sin(A)/a = sin(B)/b = sin(C)/c to find unknown sides and angles in triangles.
example_tasks: In triangle ABC, A = 40°, B = 60°, and a = 10. Find side b.
In triangle DEF, d = 15, e = 20, and D = 35°. Find angle E.
A triangle has angles 50° and 70°, with the side opposite the 50° angle measuring 12. Find the side opposite the 70° angle.

sub_topics.name: The Ambiguous Case (SSA)
sub_topics.short_description: Analyze situations where side-side-angle information may produce zero, one, or two triangles.
example_tasks: Given a = 20, b = 15, and A = 30°, determine how many triangles are possible and solve for all possibilities.
In triangle ABC, a = 10, b = 12, and A = 45°. How many triangles satisfy these conditions?
Given a = 8, b = 10, and A = 60°, determine if a triangle exists and find all solutions if it does.

sub_topics.name: Area Using Law of Sines
sub_topics.short_description: Find the area of triangles using the formula Area = (1/2)ab·sin(C).
example_tasks: Find the area of triangle ABC with a = 12, b = 8, and C = 60°.
A triangle has sides 15 and 20 with an included angle of 75°. Find its area.
Two sides of a triangle are 10 and 14, and the area is 35. Find the measure of the included angle.

sub_topics.name: Law of Cosines
sub_topics.short_description: Apply the Law of Cosines to solve triangles given SAS or SSS information.

sub_topics.name: Applying the Law of Cosines
sub_topics.short_description: Use c² = a² + b² - 2ab·cos(C) to find unknown sides or angles.
example_tasks: In triangle ABC, a = 8, b = 11, and C = 60°. Find side c.
A triangle has sides 7, 10, and 12. Find the largest angle.
In triangle DEF, d = 15, e = 20, and F = 110°. Find side f.

sub_topics.name: Solving SSS Triangles
sub_topics.short_description: Find all angles of a triangle when all three sides are known.
example_tasks: A triangle has sides 5, 6, and 7. Find all three angles.
Determine if sides 8, 15, and 20 form a valid triangle. If so, find the smallest angle.
Three sides of a triangle are 9, 12, and 15. Verify this is a right triangle using the Law of Cosines.

sub_topics.name: Solving SAS Triangles
sub_topics.short_description: Find the third side and remaining angles when two sides and the included angle are known.
example_tasks: Two sides of a triangle measure 14 and 18 with an included angle of 40°. Find the third side and the other two angles.
In triangle ABC, b = 20, c = 25, and A = 75°. Find side a and angles B and C.
A parallelogram has sides 10 and 15 with an included angle of 65°. Find the length of the shorter diagonal.

sub_topics.name: Choosing Between Laws
sub_topics.short_description: Determine whether to use Law of Sines or Law of Cosines based on given information.
example_tasks: For each set of information, state whether to use Law of Sines or Law of Cosines: (a) Two angles and a side, (b) Two sides and included angle, (c) Three sides.
A triangle has a = 12, B = 45°, and C = 60°. Which law should you use first to solve the triangle?
Given sides 8 and 10 with an angle of 50° opposite the side of length 8, which law is most appropriate and why?

sub_topics.name: Applications: Navigation and Forces
sub_topics.short_description: Apply trigonometry to solve real-world problems involving navigation, forces, and vectors.

sub_topics.name: Bearing and Navigation Problems
sub_topics.short_description: Solve navigation problems using bearings and the Laws of Sines and Cosines.
example_tasks: A ship travels 50 miles on a bearing of N 40° E, then 30 miles on a bearing of S 70° E. How far is it from its starting point?
An airplane flies 200 km on a bearing of 120°, then 150 km on a bearing of 210°. Find the distance and bearing back to the starting point.
Two ships leave port simultaneously. One travels at 20 mph on bearing 040° and the other at 25 mph on bearing 130°. How far apart are they after 3 hours?

sub_topics.name: Force and Vector Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Resolve forces into components and find resultant forces using trigonometry.
example_tasks: Two forces of 30 N and 40 N act on an object at an angle of 60° to each other. Find the magnitude of the resultant force.
A weight of 100 pounds is suspended by two ropes making angles of 30° and 45° with the horizontal. Find the tension in each rope.
A force of 50 N acts at an angle of 35° above the horizontal. Find the horizontal and vertical components of the force.

sub_topics.name: Surveying and Height Problems
sub_topics.short_description: Use angles of elevation and depression with the Laws of Sines and Cosines to solve measurement problems.
example_tasks: From two points A and B on level ground 100 feet apart, the angles of elevation to the top of a tower are 30° and 45°. Find the height of the tower.
A surveyor measures angles from point A to landmarks B and C as 75° and 42°. If B and C are 500 feet apart, how far is A from each landmark?
Two observers 2 miles apart on level ground both see a hot air balloon. Their angles of elevation are 60° and 75°. Find the altitude of the balloon.

grade_11_12.name: Analytic Geometry and Conic Sections
grade_11_12.short_description: Students analyze conic sections (parabolas, ellipses, hyperbolas) using their equations and geometric properties. This topic connects algebraic and geometric representations of important mathematical curves.

sub_topics.name: Parabolas
sub_topics.short_description: Analyze parabolas with vertical and horizontal axes, finding focus, directrix, and equations.

sub_topics.name: Definition and Standard Forms
sub_topics.short_description: Understand parabolas as sets of points equidistant from focus and directrix; use standard forms.
example_tasks: Write the equation of a parabola with vertex at the origin and focus at (0, 3).
Find the focus and directrix of the parabola y² = 8x.
Identify the vertex, focus, and directrix of (x - 2)² = 12(y + 1).

sub_topics.name: Graphing Parabolas
sub_topics.short_description: Sketch parabolas by identifying vertex, focus, directrix, and axis of symmetry.
example_tasks: Graph the parabola x² = -16y and label the vertex, focus, and directrix.
Sketch (y + 2)² = 8(x - 1) and identify all key features.
Graph y² - 4y - 8x + 12 = 0 by completing the square and finding standard form.

sub_topics.name: Applications of Parabolas
sub_topics.short_description: Apply parabolic properties to reflective surfaces, projectile motion, and engineering.
example_tasks: A satellite dish has a parabolic cross-section. If it is 6 feet across and 2 feet deep, where should the receiver be placed?
A parabolic reflector has equation y² = 16x. A light source at the focus will reflect parallel to which axis?
The cables of a suspension bridge form a parabola with equation y = 0.002x² where the origin is at the lowest point. Find the height of the cable at 100 feet from center.

sub_topics.name: Ellipses
sub_topics.short_description: Analyze ellipses using standard form equations, finding foci, vertices, and major/minor axes.

sub_topics.name: Definition and Standard Forms
sub_topics.short_description: Understand ellipses as sets of points with constant sum of distances to two foci; use equations.
example_tasks: Write the equation of an ellipse centered at the origin with vertices at (±5, 0) and co-vertices at (0, ±3).
Find the vertices and foci of the ellipse x²/25 + y²/16 = 1.
Identify the center, vertices, and foci of (x-2)²/9 + (y+1)²/4 = 1.

sub_topics.name: Graphing Ellipses
sub_topics.short_description: Sketch ellipses by identifying center, vertices, co-vertices, and foci.
example_tasks: Graph the ellipse x²/16 + y²/25 = 1 and label all key features.
Sketch (x+3)²/4 + (y-2)²/9 = 1 and identify the major axis.
Graph 9x² + 4y² = 36 by converting to standard form.

sub_topics.name: Eccentricity of Ellipses
sub_topics.short_description: Calculate and interpret eccentricity e = c/a where c² = a² - b².
example_tasks: Find the eccentricity of the ellipse x²/25 + y²/9 = 1.
An ellipse has vertices at (±10, 0) and foci at (±8, 0). Find its eccentricity.
If an ellipse has eccentricity 0.6 and major axis of length 20, find the distance between foci.

sub_topics.name: Applications of Ellipses
sub_topics.short_description: Apply ellipses to planetary orbits, architecture, and acoustics.
example_tasks: Earth's orbit is approximately an ellipse with the Sun at one focus. If the closest distance is 91.4 million miles and farthest is 94.5 million miles, find the eccentricity.
A whispering gallery has an elliptical ceiling. If the room is 40 feet long and 30 feet wide, where should two people stand to hear each other's whispers?
An elliptical track has a major axis of 200 meters and minor axis of 150 meters. Find the equation if the center is at the origin.

sub_topics.name: Hyperbolas
sub_topics.short_description: Analyze hyperbolas using standard forms, finding foci, vertices, asymptotes, and transverse axes.

sub_topics.name: Definition and Standard Forms
sub_topics.short_description: Understand hyperbolas as sets of points with constant difference of distances to foci; use equations.
example_tasks: Write the equation of a hyperbola centered at the origin with vertices at (±4, 0) and foci at (±5, 0).
Find the vertices and foci of the hyperbola x²/16 - y²/9 = 1.
Identify the center, vertices, and foci of (y+2)²/25 - (x-3)²/16 = 1.

sub_topics.name: Asymptotes of Hyperbolas
sub_topics.short_description: Find equations of asymptotes using y = ±(b/a)(x - h) + k for horizontal transverse axis.
example_tasks: Find the equations of the asymptotes for x²/9 - y²/16 = 1.
Write the asymptote equations for the hyperbola (y-1)²/4 - (x+2)²/9 = 1.
A hyperbola has center (0,0) and asymptotes y = ±(3/4)x. If a vertex is at (4,0), find its equation.

sub_topics.name: Graphing Hyperbolas
sub_topics.short_description: Sketch hyperbolas by identifying center, vertices, foci, and asymptotes.
example_tasks: Graph the hyperbola x²/25 - y²/9 = 1 showing vertices, foci, and asymptotes.
Sketch y²/16 - x²/4 = 1 and label all key features.
Graph 9y² - 4x² = 36 by converting to standard form.

sub_topics.name: Applications of Hyperbolas
sub_topics.short_description: Apply hyperbolas to navigation systems, optics, and physics.
example_tasks: Two LORAN stations 200 miles apart transmit signals simultaneously. A ship receives one signal 0.0005 seconds before the other. If radio waves travel at 186,000 miles/second, describe the ship's possible locations.
A hyperbolic mirror reflects light rays aimed at one focus toward the other focus. If foci are at (±6, 0) and vertices at (±4, 0), write the equation of the mirror's cross-section.
The path of an alpha particle deflected by a nucleus follows a hyperbolic path. If the closest approach is 3 units and the asymptotes have slopes ±2, find the equation.

sub_topics.name: Identifying and Classifying Conics
sub_topics.short_description: Identify conic sections from their general equations and classify using the discriminant.

sub_topics.name: General Form of Conics
sub_topics.short_description: Work with the general second-degree equation Ax² + Bxy + Cy² + Dx + Ey + F = 0.
example_tasks: Identify the conic: 4x² + 9y² - 16x + 18y - 11 = 0
Classify: x² - 4y² - 6x + 16y - 11 = 0
Determine the type of conic: y² + 8x - 6y + 25 = 0

sub_topics.name: Using the Discriminant
sub_topics.short_description: Use B² - 4AC to classify conics: ellipse if negative, parabola if zero, hyperbola if positive.
example_tasks: Use the discriminant to classify: 3x² + 5y² - 6x + 10y = 0
For the equation 2x² - 3xy + 4y² + x - y = 0, use the discriminant to identify the conic type.
What type of conic is represented by x² + 2xy + y² - 4x + 2y = 0?

sub_topics.name: Completing the Square for Conics
sub_topics.short_description: Convert general form equations to standard form by completing the square.
example_tasks: Convert to standard form and identify: x² + y² - 6x + 4y - 3 = 0
Complete the square to graph: 4x² + 9y² - 16x - 54y + 61 = 0
Rewrite in standard form: y² - 4x² + 6y + 16x - 29 = 0

sub_topics.name: Degenerate Conics
